           <a class="vector-toc-link" href="#Background">

             </span>
             <span>

           <ul class="vector-toc-list" id="toc-Background-sublist">
            <li class="vector-toc-list-item vector-toc-level-2" id="toc-Contemporary_politics_and_previous_elections">
             <a class="vector-toc-link" href="#Contemporary_politics_and_previous_elections">
              <div class="vector-toc-text">
               <span class="vector-toc-numb">
                1.1
               </span>
               <span>

         </style>

               </span>
              </span>
             </span>
             <hr/>
            </td>
           </tr>

                 </a>
                </td>

                 <b>
                  19 April – 1 June 2024
                  <span style="display:none">
                   (
                   <span class="dtstart">
                    2024-04-19
                   </span>
                   –
                   <span class="dtend">
                    2024-06-01
                   </span>
                   )
                  </span>
                 </b>
                </td>

             <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">

              </a>
             </sup>
             (
             <span typeof="mw:File">
              <span title="Increase">
               <img alt="Increase" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
              </span>
             </span>
             6.24%)
            </td>
           </tr>
           <tr>
            <th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="width:5em;white-space:nowrap;">
             Turnout
            </th>
            <td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:center;">
             65.79% (
             <span typeof="mw:File">
              <span title="Decrease">
               <img alt="Decrease" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
              </span>
             </span>
             1.61
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Percentage_points" title="Percentage points">
              pp
             </a>
             )
             <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2">
              <a href="#cite_note-2">
               [2]
              </a>
             </sup>
            </td>

         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
          .mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}
         </style>
         <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
          <div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:281px;max-width:281px">
           <div class="trow">
            <div class="tsingle" style="width:138px;max-width:138px">
             <div class="thumbimage" style="height:144px;overflow:hidden">
              <span typeof="mw:File">
               <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg">
                <img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1534" data-file-width="1449" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg/136px-Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg/204px-Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg/272px-Lok_Sabha_Constituencies.svg.png 2x" width="136"/>
               </a>
              </span>
             </div>
            </div>
            <div class="tsingle" style="width:139px;max-width:139px">
             <div class="thumbimage" style="height:144px;overflow:hidden">
              <span typeof="mw:File">
               <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg">
                <img alt="" class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="542" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg/137px-2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg/206px-2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg/274px-2024_Lok_Sabha_Election_Schedule.svg.png 2x" width="137"/>
               </a>
              </span>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
            <div class="thumbcaption">
             Seats by constituency (left), Election schedule (right)
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <p>
          General elections were held in
          <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_India" title="Elections in India">
           India
          </a>
          from
          <a href="/wiki/2024_elections_in_India" title="2024 elections in India">
           19 April to 1 June 2024
          </a>
          in seven phases, to elect all
          <a href="/wiki/List_of_constituencies_of_the_Lok_Sabha" title="List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha">
           543 members
          </a>
          of the
          <a href="/wiki/Lok_Sabha" title="Lok Sabha">
           Lok Sabha
          </a>
          .
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3">
           <a href="#cite_note-3">
            [a]
           </a>
          </sup>
          Votes were counted and the result was declared on 4 June to form the
          <a href="/wiki/18th_Lok_Sabha" title="18th Lok Sabha">
           18th Lok Sabha
          </a>
          .
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
           <a href="#cite_note-4">
            [3]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5">
           <a href="#cite_note-5">
            [4]
           </a>
          </sup>
          The legislative assembly elections in the states of
          <a href="/wiki/2024_Andhra_Pradesh_Legislative_Assembly_election" title="2024 Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly election">
           Andhra Pradesh
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/2024_Arunachal_Pradesh_Legislative_Assembly_election" title="2024 Arunachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly election">
           Arunachal Pradesh
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/2024_Odisha_Legislative_Assembly_election" title="2024 Odisha Legislative Assembly election">
           Odisha
          </a>
          , and
          <a href="/wiki/2024_Sikkim_Legislative_Assembly_election" title="2024 Sikkim Legislative Assembly election">
           Sikkim
          </a>
          were held simultaneously with the general election, along with the
          <a href="/wiki/2024_elections_in_India#Legislative_Assembly_by-elections" title="2024 elections in India">
           by-elections
          </a>
          for 25 constituencies in 12 legislative assemblies.
         </p>
         <p>
          More than 968 million people out of a population of 1.4 billion people were eligible to vote, equivalent to 70 percent of the total population.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
           <a href="#cite_note-6">
            [5]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_7-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-:0-7">
            [6]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_8-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-:1-8">
            [7]
           </a>
          </sup>
          642 million voters participated in the election and 312 million of them were women, making it the highest ever participation by women voters.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
           <a href="#cite_note-9">
            [8]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
           <a href="#cite_note-10">
            [9]
           </a>
          </sup>
          This was the largest-ever election, surpassing the
          <a href="/wiki/2019_Indian_general_election" title="2019 Indian general election">
           previous election
          </a>
          , and lasted 44 days, second only to the
          <a href="/wiki/1951%E2%80%9352_Indian_general_election" title="1951–52 Indian general election">
           1951–52 Indian general election
          </a>
          .
         </p>
         <p>
          Incumbent prime minister
          <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">
           Narendra Modi
          </a>
          , who completed a
          <a href="/wiki/Second_Modi_ministry" title="Second Modi ministry">
           second term
          </a>
          , ran for a third consecutive term after his
          <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
           Bharatiya Janata Party
          </a>
          (BJP) had enjoyed an
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Absolute_majority" title="Absolute majority">
           absolute majority
          </a>
          —a minimum of 272 seats—in the
          <a href="/wiki/2019_Indian_general_election" title="2019 Indian general election">
           2019
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/2014_Indian_general_election" title="2014 Indian general election">
           2014 elections
          </a>
          . The primary opposition was the
          <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance" title="Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance">
           Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance
          </a>
          (INDIA), a coalition formed by the
          <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">
           Indian National Congress
          </a>
          (INC) and many regional parties in 2023. The election was criticised for lack of action on hate speeches by Modi's BJP,
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-u255_11-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-u255-11">
            [10]
           </a>
          </sup>
          reported
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electronic_Voting_Machine" title="Electronic Voting Machine">
           Electronic Voting Machine
          </a>
          (EVM) malfunctioning,
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-h953_12-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-h953-12">
            [11]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-e533_13-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-e533-13">
            [12]
           </a>
          </sup>
          and suppression of political opponents of the BJP.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-e827_14-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-e827-14">
            [13]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </p>
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Opinion_poll" title="Opinion poll">
           Opinion surveys
          </a>
          of mainstream media outlets projected a decisive victory for the BJP and its coalition, the
          <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">
           National Democratic Alliance
          </a>
          (NDA). However, the BJP won 240 seats, down from the 303 seats it had secured in 2019, and lost its singular majority in the Lok Sabha, whereas the overall NDA secured 293 of the house's 543 seats.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
           <a href="#cite_note-15">
            [14]
           </a>
          </sup>
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance" title="Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance">
           INDIA coalition
          </a>
          outperformed expectations, securing 234 seats, 99 of which were won by the Congress, garnering the party the
          <a href="/wiki/Official_Opposition_(India)" title="Official Opposition (India)">
           Official Opposition
          </a>
          status for the first time in 10 years.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
           <a href="#cite_note-16">
            [15]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
           <a href="#cite_note-17">
            [16]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
           <a href="#cite_note-18">
            [17]
           </a>
          </sup>
          Seven independents and ten candidates from non-aligned parties also won seats in the Lok Sabha.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
           <a href="#cite_note-19">
            [18]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
           <a href="#cite_note-20">
            [19]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
           <a href="#cite_note-21">
            [20]
           </a>
          </sup>
          On 7 June 2024, Modi confirmed the support of 293 MPs to
          <a href="/wiki/Droupadi_Murmu" title="Droupadi Murmu">
           Droupadi Murmu
          </a>
          , the
          <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">
           president of India
          </a>
          .
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
           <a href="#cite_note-22">
            [21]
           </a>
          </sup>
          This marked Modi's third term as prime minister and his first time heading a
          <a href="/wiki/Coalition_government" title="Coalition government">
           coalition government
          </a>
          ,
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
           <a href="#cite_note-23">
            [22]
           </a>
          </sup>
          with the
          <a href="/wiki/Telugu_Desam_Party" title="Telugu Desam Party">
           Telugu Desam Party
          </a>
          of
          <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">
           Andhra Pradesh
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)" title="Janata Dal (United)">
           Janata Dal (United)
          </a>
          of
          <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">
           Bihar
          </a>
          emerging as two main allies.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
           <a href="#cite_note-24">
            [23]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
           <a href="#cite_note-25">
            [24]
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
           <a href="#cite_note-26">
            [25]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </p>
         <meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Background">
            Background
           </span>
          </h2>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_politics_and_previous_elections">
            Contemporary politics and previous elections
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           India has a
           <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
            multi-party system
           </a>
           with two major parties, namely the
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
            Bharatiya Janata Party
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">
            Indian National Congress
           </a>
           , that dominate politics at the national level. The BJP has governed the country with
           <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">
            Narendra Modi
           </a>
           at the helm since 2014. The tenure of the
           <a href="/wiki/17th_Lok_Sabha" title="17th Lok Sabha">
            17th Lok Sabha
           </a>
           is scheduled to end on 16 June 2024.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Terms_of_the_Houses_27-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Terms_of_the_Houses-27">
             [26]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/2019_Indian_general_election" title="2019 Indian general election">
            previous general election
           </a>
           was held in April–May 2019, after which the
           <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">
            National Democratic Alliance
           </a>
           , led by the BJP, formed the
           <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">
            union government
           </a>
           , with Modi continuing as
           <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India" title="Prime Minister of India">
            Prime Minister
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Narendra_Modi_28-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Narendra_Modi-28">
             [27]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, comprising of 26 opposition parties, was formed in 2023 to contest the BJP in the 2024 Lok Sabha elections.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
            <a href="#cite_note-29">
             [28]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Electoral_system">
            Electoral system
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           Article 83 of the
           <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">
            Constitution of India
           </a>
           requires elections to the Lok Sabha to be held once every five years.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution_of_India_30-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Constitution_of_India-30">
             [29]
            </a>
           </sup>
           All 543 elected
           <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament,_Lok_Sabha" title="Member of Parliament, Lok Sabha">
            MPs
           </a>
           are elected from single-member constituencies using
           <a href="/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting" title="First-past-the-post voting">
            first-past-the-post voting
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
            <a href="#cite_note-31">
             [30]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/One_Hundred_and_Fourth_Amendment_of_the_Constitution_of_India" title="One Hundred and Fourth Amendment of the Constitution of India">
            104th amendment
           </a>
           to the
           <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">
            constitution
           </a>
           abolished the
           <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indian_reserved_seats_in_the_Lok_Sabha" title="Anglo-Indian reserved seats in the Lok Sabha">
            two seats that were reserved
           </a>
           for the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Indian" title="Anglo-Indian">
            Anglo-Indian
           </a>
           community.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_32-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-:4-32">
             [31]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           Eligible voters must be Indian citizens, 18 years or older, ordinary residents of the polling area of the constituency and registered to vote (name included in the electoral rolls), possess a valid
           <a href="/wiki/Voter_ID_(India)" title="Voter ID (India)">
            voter identification card
           </a>
           issued by the
           <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_India" title="Election Commission of India">
            Election Commission of India
           </a>
           or equivalent.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_33-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-:5-33">
             [32]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Some people convicted of electoral or other offenses are barred from voting.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-General_Voters_34-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-General_Voters-34">
             [33]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Indians holding foreign citizenship are also barred from voting. There is no postal or online
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Absentee_voting" title="Absentee voting">
            absentee voting
           </a>
           in India; members of the
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_diaspora" title="Indian diaspora">
            Indian diaspora
           </a>
           are required to travel back to their home constituencies in order to cast a ballot.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diaspora_35-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-diaspora-35">
             [34]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           For the 2024 election, 968 million people are eligible to vote, an increase of about 150 million people from the 2019 election.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-seven_stages_36-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-seven_stages-36">
             [35]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In
           <a href="/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh" title="Arunachal Pradesh">
            Arunachal Pradesh
           </a>
           , a polling station will be set up for the only registered voter in the village of Malogam, due to electoral laws that stipulate voting booths to be placed within two kilometres (1.2 mi) from all settlements.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
            <a href="#cite_note-37">
             [36]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
            <a href="#cite_note-38">
             [37]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-f5.5_39-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-f5.5-39">
             [38]
            </a>
           </sup>
           A polling station was also set up inside the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gir_Forest" title="Gir Forest">
            Gir Forest
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">
            Gujarat
           </a>
           to cater for a singular voter, a priest at a Hindu temple.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
            <a href="#cite_note-40">
             [39]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Polling stations will also be set up inside a wildlife sanctuary in
           <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">
            Kerala
           </a>
           and in a shipping container in Gujarat,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
            <a href="#cite_note-41">
             [40]
            </a>
           </sup>
           as well as in 320 relief camps hosting some 59,000 people displaced during
           <a href="/wiki/2023%E2%80%932024_Manipur_violence" title="2023–2024 Manipur violence">
            interethnic violence
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Manipur" title="Manipur">
            Manipur
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
            <a href="#cite_note-42">
             [41]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           In March 2024, the
           <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India" title="Supreme Court of India">
            Supreme Court of India
           </a>
           rejected a petition by the Congress Party to end the usage of
           <a href="/wiki/Electronic_voting_in_India" title="Electronic voting in India">
            electronic voting
           </a>
           machines and revert to paper ballots and manual counting, which was the system used in elections until the late 1990s, with the party citing risks of electoral fraud.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
            <a href="#cite_note-43">
             [42]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Nearly 5.5 million electronic voting machines were to be utilized for more than one million polling stations, while 15 million election workers and security personnel were to be tasked with managing the conduct of the election.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-f5.5_39-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-f5.5-39">
             [38]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           For the first time, the Election Commission of India allowed voters with disabilities and those over the age of 85 to cast ballots from their homes due to concerns over high temperatures. In
           <a href="/wiki/Telangana" title="Telangana">
            Telangana
           </a>
           , voting in some precincts was extended by a later hour to allow voters to come at a more convenient time.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
            <a href="#cite_note-44">
             [43]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Planning">
            Planning
           </span>
          </h3>
          <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb">
           <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg">
            <img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1563" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg/220px-Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg/330px-Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg/440px-Chief_Election_Commissioner_announced_the_2024_General_Elections_schedule_for_Lok_Sabha_and_State_Legislative_Assemblies_during_a_press_conference.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
           </a>
           <figcaption>
            Chief Election Commissioner
            <a href="/wiki/Rajiv_Kumar_(civil_servant)" title="Rajiv Kumar (civil servant)">
             Rajiv Kumar
            </a>
            announced the 2024 General Elections schedule for Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies during a press conference
           </figcaption>
          </figure>
          <p>
           Key processes during a Lok Sabha election involve monitoring campaign expenditure, preventing the circulation of illicit goods, and ensuring adherence to the Model Code of Conduct. In the final 48 hours before voting, campaigns are ended, and measures are implemented to maintain order and prevent disruptions. On polling day, strict rules are enforced to prevent undue influence, ensuring a smooth and secure election process. Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) are sealed and stored with tight security measures, while Booth Level Officers assist voters throughout the process.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
            <a href="#cite_note-45">
             [44]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Schedule">
            Schedule
           </span>
          </h2>
          <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">
           .mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}
          </style>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable relarticle mainarticle selfreference noprint" role="note">
           This section is
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Transclusion" title="Help:Transclusion">
            transcluded
           </a>
           from
           <a href="/wiki/Election_schedule_of_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="Election schedule of the 2024 Indian general election">
            Election schedule of the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
           .
           <span class="plainlinks" style="font-style: normal; font-size:85%;">
            (
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Election_schedule_of_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=edit">
             edit
            </a>
            |
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Election_schedule_of_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=history">
             history
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </div>
          <p>
           The election schedule for the 18th Lok Sabha was announced by the
           <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_India" title="Election Commission of India">
            Election Commission of India
           </a>
           on 16 March 2024,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
            <a href="#cite_note-46">
             [45]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
            <a href="#cite_note-47">
             [46]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and with it the
           <a href="/wiki/Model_Code_of_Conduct" title="Model Code of Conduct">
            Model Code of Conduct
           </a>
           came into effect.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
            <a href="#cite_note-48">
             [47]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The tenure of the
           <a href="/wiki/17th_Lok_Sabha" title="17th Lok Sabha">
            17th Lok Sabha
           </a>
           is scheduled to end on 16 June 2024.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
            <a href="#cite_note-49">
             [48]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>

            </tr>

             <th>
              No. of constituencies
             </th>
             <td>
              <b>
               <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1154941027">

               </style>
               <span class="frac">
                101

              </span>

               <a href="/wiki/Barasat_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Barasat Lok Sabha constituency">
                Barasat
               </a>
               and
               <a href="/wiki/Mathurapur_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Mathurapur Lok Sabha constituency">
                Mathurapur
               </a>
               constituencies of West Bengal were held on 3 June due to violence.
              </span>

           </div>
          </div>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Parties_and_alliances">
            Parties and alliances
           </span>
          </h2>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_India" title="List of political parties in India">
            List of political parties in India
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The politics of India has become increasingly bipolar in the run-up to the 2024 Indian general elections with two major alliances emerging; the incumbent
           <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">
            NDA (National Democratic Alliance)
           </a>
           and the opposition
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance" title="Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance">
            INDIA (Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance)
           </a>
           . Six national parties are contesting the 2024 Indian general elections:
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
            BJP (Bharatiya Janata Party)
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">
            INC (Indian National Congress)
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)" title="Communist Party of India (Marxist)">
            CPI(M) (Communist Party of India (Marxist))
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Bahujan_Samaj_Party" title="Bahujan Samaj Party">
            BSP (Bahujan Samaj Party)
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Party_(India)" title="National People's Party (India)">
            NPP (National People's Party)
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party" title="Aam Aadmi Party">
            AAP (Aam Aadmi Party)
           </a>
           with all except the BSP being a part of one of the two alliances.
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span id="National_Democratic_Alliance_.28NDA.29">
           </span>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="National_Democratic_Alliance_(NDA)">
            National Democratic Alliance (NDA)
           </span>
          </h3>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">
            National Democratic Alliance
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The National Democratic Alliance, abbreviated as NDA (
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IAST" title="IAST">
            IAST
           </a>
           : Rāṣṭrīya Janatāntrik Gaṭhabandhan) is a
           <a href="/wiki/Big_tent" title="Big tent">
            big tent
           </a>
           , mostly
           <a href="/wiki/Centre-right_politics" title="Centre-right politics">
            centre-right
           </a>
           to
           <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">
            right-wing
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_group" title="Parliamentary group">
            political alliance
           </a>
           led by the
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
            Bharatiya Janata Party
           </a>
           .
          </p>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable relarticle mainarticle selfreference noprint" role="note">
           This section is
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Transclusion" title="Help:Transclusion">
            transcluded
           </a>
           from
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_National_Democratic_Alliance_candidates_in_the_2024_Indian_general_election#Seat_sharing_summary" title="List of National Democratic Alliance candidates in the 2024 Indian general election">
            List of National Democratic Alliance candidates in the 2024 Indian general election#Seat sharing summary
           </a>
           .
           <span class="plainlinks" style="font-style: normal; font-size:85%;">
            (
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_National_Democratic_Alliance_candidates_in_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=edit#Seat_sharing_summary">
             edit
            </a>
            |
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_National_Democratic_Alliance_candidates_in_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=history#Seat_sharing_summary">
             history
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </div>

          <h3>
           <span id="Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_.28INDIA.29">
           </span>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_(INDIA)">
            Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA)
           </span>
          </h3>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance" title="Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance">
            Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, abbreviated as INDIA (
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IAST" title="IAST">
            IAST
           </a>
           :
           <i>
            <span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">
             <i lang="sa-Latn">
              Bhāratīya Rāṣṭrīya Vikāsaśīla Samāveśī Gaṭhabaṃdhana
             </i>
            </span>
           </i>
           ) is a
           <a href="/wiki/Big_tent" title="Big tent">
            big-tent
           </a>
           , mostly
           <a href="/wiki/Centre-left_politics" title="Centre-left politics">
            centre-left
           </a>
           to
           <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_politics" title="Left-wing politics">
            left-wing
           </a>
           bloc of
           <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_opposition" title="Parliamentary opposition">
            opposition parties
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
            <a href="#cite_note-58">
             [54]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
            <a href="#cite_note-59">
             [55]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           In the run up to the general election numerous opposition parties met to form a new opposition alliance to defeat the ruling
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
            Bharatiya Janata Party
           </a>
           . After numerous talks 26 political parties came together to form the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA).
          </p>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable relarticle mainarticle selfreference noprint" role="note">
           This section is
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Transclusion" title="Help:Transclusion">
            transcluded
           </a>
           from
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_candidates_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election#Seat_sharing_summary" title="List of Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance candidates for the 2024 Indian general election">
            List of Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance candidates for the 2024 Indian general election#Seat sharing summary
           </a>
           .
           <span class="plainlinks" style="font-style: normal; font-size:85%;">
            (
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_candidates_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=edit#Seat_sharing_summary">
             edit
            </a>
            |
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_candidates_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=history#Seat_sharing_summary">
             history
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </div>
          <h3>

          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_notable_parties_and_alliances">
            Other notable parties and alliances
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           <a href="/wiki/Bahujan_Samaj_Party" title="Bahujan Samaj Party">
            Bahujan Samaj Party
           </a>
           leader
           <a href="/wiki/Mayawati" title="Mayawati">
            Mayawati
           </a>
           announced that her party will contest the election on its own in most states and ally with other non-BJP, non-Congress parties in Telangana and Haryana.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
            <a href="#cite_note-65">
             [61]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           On 11 May 2023,
           <a href="/wiki/Biju_Janata_Dal" title="Biju Janata Dal">
            Biju Janata Dal
           </a>
           leader and Chief Minister of Odisha
           <a href="/wiki/Naveen_Patnaik" title="Naveen Patnaik">
            Naveen Patnaik
           </a>
           said that his party will go alone for the Lok Sabha polls in Odisha.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
            <a href="#cite_note-66">
             [62]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1224903325" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          </p>
          <table class="wikitable sortable sticky-header" style="text-align:center" width="50%">
           <tbody>
            <tr>
             <th colspan="2" style="width:17px;">
              Party/Alliance
             </th>

             </td>
             <td>
              1
             </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
             <td>
              Rajasthan
             </td>

          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Candidates">
            Candidates
           </span>
          </h2>
          <p>
           The prime ministerial candidate for the 2024 general election of the NDA alliance is the incumbent Prime Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">
            Narendra Modi
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
            <a href="#cite_note-67">
             [63]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
            <a href="#cite_note-68">
             [64]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The prime ministerial candidate of the INDIA bloc will be decided after the 2024 polls.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
            <a href="#cite_note-69">
             [65]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
            <a href="#cite_note-70">
             [66]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="National_Democratic_Alliance">
            National Democratic Alliance
           </span>
          </h3>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_National_Democratic_Alliance_candidates_in_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="List of National Democratic Alliance candidates in the 2024 Indian general election">
            List of National Democratic Alliance candidates in the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
          </div>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Bharatiya_Janata_Party">
            Bharatiya Janata Party
           </span>
          </h4>
          <figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb">
           <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg">
            <img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1700" data-file-width="1380" decoding="async" height="431" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg/350px-2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg/525px-2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg/700px-2024_NDA_Alliance_Lok_Sabha_Seat_Sharing.svg.png 2x" width="350"/>
           </a>
           <figcaption>
            National Democratic Alliance's Lok Sabha Seat Sharing for the election
           </figcaption>
          </figure>
          <p>
           The BJP announced its first list of 195 candidates on 2 March 2024
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
            <a href="#cite_note-71">
             [67]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
            <a href="#cite_note-72">
             [68]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the second list of 72 candidates was published in 13 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
            <a href="#cite_note-73">
             [69]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the third list of nine candidates was announced on 21 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
            <a href="#cite_note-74">
             [70]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The fourth list of 15 candidates was released on 22 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
            <a href="#cite_note-75">
             [71]
            </a>
           </sup>
           followed by the declaration of fifth list of 111 candidates on 24 March
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
            <a href="#cite_note-76">
             [72]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the sixth list of three candidates on 26 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
            <a href="#cite_note-77">
             [73]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The seventh list of two candidates was announced on 27 March
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
            <a href="#cite_note-78">
             [74]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the eighth list of eleven candidates was published on 30 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
            <a href="#cite_note-79">
             [75]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the ninth list of just one candidate was released on 31 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
            <a href="#cite_note-80">
             [76]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The tenth list, comprising nine candidates, was released on 10 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
            <a href="#cite_note-81">
             [77]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the eleventh list, comprising one candidate, was released on 11 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
            <a href="#cite_note-82">
             [78]
            </a>
           </sup>
           followed by the announcement of twelfth list of seven candidates on 16 April.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
            <a href="#cite_note-83">
             [79]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The thirteenth, fourteenth and fifteenth lists, each comprising of one candidate, were published on 18 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
            <a href="#cite_note-84">
             [80]
            </a>
           </sup>
           23 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
            <a href="#cite_note-85">
             [81]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and 27 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
            <a href="#cite_note-86">
             [82]
            </a>
           </sup>
           respectively. The sixteenth list consisting of one candidate of
           <a href="/wiki/Birbhum_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Birbhum Lok Sabha constituency">
            Birbhum constituency
           </a>
           was released on 1 May,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
            <a href="#cite_note-87">
             [83]
            </a>
           </sup>
           after previous candidate's nomination papers were rejected by the
           <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_India" title="Election Commission of India">
            ECI
           </a>
           officials
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
            <a href="#cite_note-88">
             [84]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the seventeenth list of two candidates was published on 2 May,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
            <a href="#cite_note-89">
             [85]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the eighteenth list of one candidate was declared on 3 May.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
            <a href="#cite_note-90">
             [86]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The nineteenth list of three candidates was declared on 8 May,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
            <a href="#cite_note-91">
             [87]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the twentieth list of one candidate was released on 10 May.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
            <a href="#cite_note-92">
             [88]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           For the first time since
           <a href="/wiki/1996_Indian_general_election" title="1996 Indian general election">
            1996
           </a>
           , the BJP did not field candidates in the
           <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_division" title="Kashmir division">
            Kashmir division
           </a>
           , with analysts and opposition politicians attributing it to popular backlash over the BJP government's revocation of
           <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(state)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (state)">
            Jammu and Kashmir
           </a>
           's autonomy enshrined under
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Article_370" title="Article 370">
            Article 370
           </a>
           of the Indian Constitution in 2019.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
            <a href="#cite_note-93">
             [89]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance">
            Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance
           </span>
          </h3>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_candidates_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="List of Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance candidates for the 2024 Indian general election">
            List of Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance candidates for the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
          </div>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_National_Congress">
            Indian National Congress
           </span>
          </h4>
          <p>
           The Indian National Congress released its first list of 39 candidates on 8 March 2024
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
            <a href="#cite_note-94">
             [90]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the second list of 43 candidates was published on 13 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
            <a href="#cite_note-95">
             [91]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the third list of 56 candidates was announced on 22 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
            <a href="#cite_note-96">
             [92]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The fourth list of 46 candidates was published on 23 March and the fifth list of three candidates was released on 24 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Economic_Times_97-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-The_Economic_Times-97">
             [93]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the sixth list of five candidates was announced on 25 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
            <a href="#cite_note-98">
             [94]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The seventh list of five candidates was published on 26 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
            <a href="#cite_note-99">
             [95]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the eighth list of 14 candidates was announced on 27 March
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
            <a href="#cite_note-100">
             [96]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the ninth list of five candidates was released on 29 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
            <a href="#cite_note-101">
             [97]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The tenth list of two candidates was published on 1 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
            <a href="#cite_note-102">
             [98]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the eleventh list of 17 candidates was announced on 2 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
            <a href="#cite_note-103">
             [99]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the twelfth list of three candidates was released on 4 April.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
            <a href="#cite_note-104">
             [100]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The thirteenth list of six candidates was announced on 6 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
            <a href="#cite_note-105">
             [101]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the fourteenth list of six more candidates was declared on 9 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
            <a href="#cite_note-106">
             [102]
            </a>
           </sup>
           followed by the fifteenth list of two candidates on 10 April.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
            <a href="#cite_note-107">
             [103]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The sixteenth list of 16 candidates was announced on 13 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
            <a href="#cite_note-108">
             [104]
            </a>
           </sup>
           followed by the declaration of seventeenth list of ten candidates on 14 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
            <a href="#cite_note-109">
             [105]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the eighteenth list of three candidates was published on 16 April.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
            <a href="#cite_note-110">
             [106]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The nineteenth list of four candidates was announced on 20 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
            <a href="#cite_note-111">
             [107]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the twentieth list of 11 candidates was published on 21 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
            <a href="#cite_note-112">
             [108]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the twenty-first list of seven candidates was declared on 23 April.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
            <a href="#cite_note-113">
             [109]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The twenty-second list of three candidates was published on 24 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
            <a href="#cite_note-114">
             [110]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the twenty-third list of eight candidates was announced on 25 April,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
            <a href="#cite_note-115">
             [111]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the twenty-fourth list of two candidates was declared on 28 April.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
            <a href="#cite_note-116">
             [112]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The twenty-fifth list of four candidates was published on 30 April
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
            <a href="#cite_note-117">
             [113]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and the twenty-sixth list of two candidates was announced on 3 May,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
            <a href="#cite_note-118">
             [114]
            </a>
           </sup>
           while the twenty-seventh list of one candidate, the replacement candidate for
           <a href="/wiki/Puri_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Puri Lok Sabha constituency">
            Puri
           </a>
           constituency was announced on 5 May,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
            <a href="#cite_note-119">
             [115]
            </a>
           </sup>
           after the previous candidate withdrew her candidature citing a lack of funding from the party for her election campaign.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
            <a href="#cite_note-120">
             [116]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The twenty-eighth list of one candidate was announced on 7 May.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
            <a href="#cite_note-121">
             [117]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_parties">
            Other parties
           </span>
          </h4>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           See also:
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_Left_Front_candidates_in_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="List of Left Front candidates in the 2024 Indian general election">
            List of Left Front candidates in the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress" title="All India Trinamool Congress">
            All India Trinamool Congress
           </a>
           announced its list of 42 candidates for the
           <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">
            West Bengal
           </a>
           parliamentary seats on 10 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
            <a href="#cite_note-122">
             [118]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           In the
           <a href="/wiki/Left_Front_(West_Bengal)" title="Left Front (West Bengal)">
            Left Front
           </a>
           , the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CPI(M)" title="CPI(M)">
            CPI(M)
           </a>
           announced its list first list of 44 candidates contesting from 13 different states on 28 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
            <a href="#cite_note-123">
             [119]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Major_election_issues">
            Major election issues
           </span>
          </h2>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Unemployment">
            Unemployment
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           The issue of unemployment has been a major problem for the Indian economy, especially affecting the youth.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Modi_problem_124-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Modi_problem-124">
             [120]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
            <a href="#cite_note-125">
             [121]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Unemployment in India has been at a 45-year old high.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
            <a href="#cite_note-126">
             [122]
            </a>
           </sup>
           According to a 2022
           <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
            World Bank
           </a>
           report, India's youth unemployment rate stood at 23.2%,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
            <a href="#cite_note-127">
             [123]
            </a>
           </sup>
           whereas the national unemployment hovered around 7%.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Modi_problem_124-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-Modi_problem-124">
             [120]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In 2023, 42.3% of graduates were unemployed, showing the lack of job growth needed to accommodate the increasing workforce.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
            <a href="#cite_note-128">
             [124]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           As such, unemployment has taken a centre stage in the election campaigns, with the opposition
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance" title="Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance">
            Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance
           </a>
           banking on rising unemployment and inflation to criticise the BJP government's handling of the Indian economy.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
            <a href="#cite_note-129">
             [125]
            </a>
           </sup>
           As a part of its separate youth manifesto, the
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">
            Congress
           </a>
           -led INDIA bloc promised to fill in the 3 million vacancies in government jobs and bring in the "Right to Apprenticeship", in which any diploma and degree holder up to the age of 25 can demand employment for one year and they will get a one-year salary of ₹100,000 for the term of the job.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
            <a href="#cite_note-130">
             [126]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Ram_Mandir_consecration_ceremony_and_sectarianism">
            Ram Mandir consecration ceremony and sectarianism
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           The BJP prepared a pamphlet for the Ram Mandir Inauguration Programmes to connect with families across the nation. After the
           <a href="/wiki/Consecration_of_the_Ram_Mandir" title="Consecration of the Ram Mandir">
            consecration of the Ram Mandir
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Ayodhya" title="Ayodhya">
            Ayodhya
           </a>
           , a new era of
           <a href="/wiki/Hindu_nationalism" title="Hindu nationalism">
            Hindu nationalistic sentiments
           </a>
           have dominated the
           <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_India" title="Politics of India">
            political sphere in India
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ModiRidesFT_131-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-ModiRidesFT-131">
             [127]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-How_temple_movement_helped_BJP_132-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-How_temple_movement_helped_BJP-132">
             [128]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Modi kept a long-standing political pledge of the reconstruction of the Ram Mandir and was seen to have fulfilled the BJP's manifesto to the nation's Hindu population.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-How_temple_movement_helped_BJP_132-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-How_temple_movement_helped_BJP-132">
             [128]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The Hindu nationalist ideology of Modi and the BJP has also garnered substantial support from Hindu community members.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
            <a href="#cite_note-133">
             [129]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
            <a href="#cite_note-134">
             [130]
            </a>
           </sup>
           At the same time,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">
            Bollywood
           </a>
           productions have been released with themes supporting the Modi government's policies and Hindu nationalist ideologies.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
            <a href="#cite_note-135">
             [131]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In response to such concerns, BJP spokesperson
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mmhonlumo_Kikon" title="Mmhonlumo Kikon">
            Mmhonlumo Kikon
           </a>
           acknowledged the existence of a "level of threat perception", but said that the party was trying to change that.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
            <a href="#cite_note-136">
             [132]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           A major controversy was stirred when the opposition Congress Party and its leaders declined an invitation to the Ram Mandir consecration ceremony, saying that the event was politicised into a 'BJP-RSS event'.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
            <a href="#cite_note-137">
             [133]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Assam chief minister
           <a href="/wiki/Himanta_Biswa_Sarma" title="Himanta Biswa Sarma">
            Himanta Biswa Sarma
           </a>
           said that the invitation was an opportunity for the Congress to 'reduce its sin', and that history would continue to judge it as 'anti-Hindu'.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
            <a href="#cite_note-138">
             [134]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The four
           <a href="/wiki/Shankaracharya" title="Shankaracharya">
            Shankaracharyas
           </a>
           also declined attending the event, stating that the ceremony was politicised as a campaign event at the half-built temple.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
            <a href="#cite_note-139">
             [135]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
            <a href="#cite_note-140">
             [136]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           During a campaign rally in
           <a href="/wiki/Rajasthan" title="Rajasthan">
            Rajasthan
           </a>
           on 21 April, Narendra Modi accused the Congress party of prioritizing Muslim access to national wealth and planning to distribute resources among "those who have more children" and "infiltrators" once it was in power, which reflected stereotypes about Muslims reproducing in greater numbers and conspiracy theories pushed by the BJP that Muslims were planning to outnumber Hindus. Congress leader Mallikarjun Kharge called Modi's remarks a panic-filled "hate speech" and a ploy to divert attention from the opposition outperforming the BJP during the first phase of the election, while officials in Rajasthan received complaints from the
           <a href="/wiki/Azad_Adhikar_Sena" title="Azad Adhikar Sena">
            Azad Adhikar Sena
           </a>
           and a non-profit organisation demanding Modi's arrest and for his campaign to be suspended.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc.com_141-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-bbc.com-141">
             [137]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aljazeera.com_142-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-aljazeera.com-142">
             [138]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           A complaint letter by the
           <i>
            Samvidhan Bacchao Nagrik Abhiyan
           </i>
           (Save the Constitution Citizens' Campaign) organisation to the
           <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_India" title="Election Commission of India">
            Election Commission of India
           </a>
           , signed by over 17,400 people, alleged that Modi had violated the
           <a href="/wiki/Model_Code_of_Conduct" title="Model Code of Conduct">
            Model Code of Conduct
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Representation_of_the_People_Act,_1951" title="Representation of the People Act, 1951">
            Representation of the People Act, 1951
           </a>
           by making a speech "aiming at not only appealing to 'communal feelings' but also instigating and aggravating hatred in the Hindus against Muslims".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-india.com_143-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-india.com-143">
             [139]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scroll.in_144-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-scroll.in-144">
             [140]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Electoral_Bonds">
            Electoral Bonds
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           On 15 February 2024, the
           <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India" title="Supreme Court of India">
            Supreme Court of India
           </a>
           ruled that the
           <a href="/wiki/Electoral_Bond" title="Electoral Bond">
            Electoral Bond
           </a>
           system of campaign financing that was introduced by the Modi government in 2017 which allowed individuals and companies to donate money to political parties anonymously and without limits was unconstitutional, saying that the process allowed donors to assert "influence over policymaking".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
            <a href="#cite_note-145">
             [141]
            </a>
           </sup>
           On 18 March, the court ordered the
           <a href="/wiki/State_Bank_of_India" title="State Bank of India">
            State Bank of India
           </a>
           (SBI) to provide all records regarding the electoral bonds to the Election Commission of India by 21 March in order to match electoral donors with their recipients and rejected a plea by the
           <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_Indian_Industry" title="Confederation of Indian Industry">
            Confederation of Indian Industry
           </a>
           , the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federation_of_Indian_Chambers_of_Commerce_and_Industry" title="Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry">
            Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry
           </a>
           , and the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Associated_Chambers_of_Commerce_and_Industry_of_India" title="Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India">
            Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India
           </a>
           from divulging the identities of donors. Initial reports suggest that among the leading donors to political parties were some of India's largest firms such as
           <a href="/wiki/Vedanta_Limited" title="Vedanta Limited">
            Vedanta Limited
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Bharti_Airtel" title="Bharti Airtel">
            Bharti Airtel
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RPSG_Group" title="RPSG Group">
            RPSG Group
           </a>
           and Essel Mining. It also found that the BJP was the recipient of nearly half of all recorded donations.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
            <a href="#cite_note-146">
             [142]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           In total, the top five political parties in terms of electoral bonds received are the BJP, which received Rs 6,060.5
           <a href="/wiki/Crore" title="Crore">
            crore
           </a>
           , the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress" title="All India Trinamool Congress">
            All India Trinamool Congress
           </a>
           (TMC), which received Rs 1,609.5 crore, the Congress Party, with Rs 1,421.8 crore, the
           <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Rashtra_Samithi" title="Bharat Rashtra Samithi">
            Bharat Rashtra Samithi
           </a>
           (BRS), which received Rs 1,214.7 crore, and the
           <a href="/wiki/Biju_Janata_Dal" title="Biju Janata Dal">
            Biju Janata Dal
           </a>
           (BJD), which received Rs 775.5 crore.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
            <a href="#cite_note-147">
             [143]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
            <a href="#cite_note-148">
             [144]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
            <a href="#cite_note-149">
             [145]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The biggest buyer of electoral bonds was found to be Santiago Martin, the
           <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">
            Tamil Nadu
           </a>
           -based head of the lottery firm Future Gaming and Hotel Services Private Limited, who bought bonds worth 13.68 billion rupees ($163 million) between 2020 and 2024 and made donations to the TMC, the BJP, and the
           <a href="/wiki/Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam" title="Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam">
            Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam
           </a>
           (DMK), which rules Tamil Nadu. The biggest single donor to any political party was Megha Engineering and Infrastructure Limited (MEIL), a construction firm based in
           <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad" title="Hyderabad">
            Hyderabad
           </a>
           that bought electoral bonds worth over 12 billion rupees ($144 million) between 2019 and 2024 and made donations to the
           <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Rashtra_Samithi" title="Bharat Rashtra Samithi">
            Bharat Rashtra Samithi
           </a>
           (BRS), the BJP, and the Congress Party, who alternated in ruling
           <a href="/wiki/Telangana" title="Telangana">
            Telangana
           </a>
           during that time.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ajlaundry_150-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-ajlaundry-150">
             [146]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           Some politicians from the opposition have termed Electoral Bonds a "scam" and an "extortion racket".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
            <a href="#cite_note-151">
             [147]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
