            <a href="#cite_note-152">
             [148]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
            <a href="#cite_note-153">
             [149]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In response to allegations regarding the electoral bonds, BJP spokesperson
           <a href="/wiki/Syed_Zafar_Islam" title="Syed Zafar Islam">
            Syed Zafar Islam
           </a>
           denied that the party had done any wrongdoing and said that its electoral bonds were gained "on merit".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ajlaundry_150-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-ajlaundry-150">
             [146]
            </a>
           </sup>
           However, Indian political observers have reached the conclusion that either Indian businessmen have been regularly bribing their way out of trouble, or that the BJP-controlled government has been using government agencies to extort them. From the data released by the SBI, it was found that companies gave donations around the time they received major government contracts. Close to half of the top 30 corporate donors were facing investigations by government agencies around the time they purchased electoral bonds.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
            <a href="#cite_note-154">
             [150]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
            <a href="#cite_note-155">
             [151]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
            <a href="#cite_note-156">
             [152]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Party_campaigns">
            Party campaigns
           </span>
          </h2>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Bharatiya_Janata_Party_2">
            Bharatiya Janata Party
           </span>
          </h3>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party_campaign_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="Bharatiya Janata Party campaign for the 2024 Indian general election">
            Bharatiya Janata Party campaign for the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The national executive meeting of the BJP held on 16 and 17 January 2023 saw the party reaffirm its faith in Prime Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">
            Narendra Modi
           </a>
           and extend the tenure of BJP national president
           <a href="/wiki/J._P._Nadda" title="J. P. Nadda">
            J. P. Nadda
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
            <a href="#cite_note-157">
             [153]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           Charting out the BJP's strategy for the upcoming polls, Modi said in a speech to party workers that they should reach out to every section of society, including the marginalised and minority communities, "without electoral considerations".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
            <a href="#cite_note-158">
             [154]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           Following the
           <a href="/wiki/2023_elections_in_India#State_legislative_assembly_elections" title="2023 elections in India">
            2023 Legislative Assembly elections
           </a>
           , Modi debuted the slogan "Modi Ki Guarantee" for the 2024 polls.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
            <a href="#cite_note-159">
             [155]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Another slogan used was
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Abki_Baar_400_Paar" title="Abki Baar 400 Paar">
             Abki Baar 400 Paar
            </a>
           </i>
           (This Time Surpassing 400),
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
            <a href="#cite_note-160">
             [156]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
            <a href="#cite_note-161">
             [157]
            </a>
           </sup>
           referring to the party's goal of winning more than 400 out of 543 seats in the Lok Sabha.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
            <a href="#cite_note-162">
             [158]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Having been used by the BJP in previous elections, including the
           <a href="/wiki/2019_Indian_general_election" title="2019 Indian general election">
            2019 general election
           </a>
           with some changes,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
            <a href="#cite_note-163">
             [159]
            </a>
           </sup>
           election analysts have said that the path for the BJP to achieve this goal will likely be by winning more seats in the south of India than in previous elections.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
            <a href="#cite_note-164">
             [160]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           <br/>
           The party held
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_rallies" title="Political rallies">
            political rallies
           </a>
           in multiple states with national leadership including Modi,
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="List of presidents of the Bharatiya Janata Party">
            BJP President
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/J._P._Nadda" title="J. P. Nadda">
            J. P. Nadda
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Amit_Shah" title="Amit Shah">
            Amit Shah
           </a>
           campaigning actively.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
            <a href="#cite_note-165">
             [161]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
            <a href="#cite_note-166">
             [162]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
            <a href="#cite_note-167">
             [163]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           During a campaign rally,
           <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">
            Uttar Pradesh
           </a>
           chief minister
           <a href="/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath" title="Yogi Adityanath">
            Yogi Adityanath
           </a>
           described the election as a contest between "devotees of
           <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">
            Ram
           </a>
           " and "anti-Ram forces" and urged voters to select the former. Modi also accused the opposition of plotting to raze the Ram Mandir temple once they were in power.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-apphase5_168-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-apphase5-168">
             [164]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           During a campaign rally in
           <a href="/wiki/Rajasthan" title="Rajasthan">
            Rajasthan
           </a>
           on 21 April, Narendra Modi accused the Congress party of prioritizing Muslim access to national wealth and planning to distribute resources among "those who have more children" and "infiltrators" once it was in power, which reflected stereotypes about Muslims reproducing in greater numbers and conspiracy theories pushed by the BJP that Muslims were planning to outnumber Hindus. Congress leader Mallikarjun Kharge called Modi's remarks a panic-filled "hate speech" and a ploy to divert attention from the opposition outperforming the BJP during the first phase of the election, while officials in Rajasthan received complaints from the
           <a href="/wiki/Azad_Adhikar_Sena" title="Azad Adhikar Sena">
            Azad Adhikar Sena
           </a>
           and a non-profit organisation demanding Modi's arrest and for his campaign to be suspended.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc.com_141-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-bbc.com-141">
             [137]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aljazeera.com_142-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-aljazeera.com-142">
             [138]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Following Modi's speech, the BJP posted an animated video on its official
           <a href="/wiki/Instagram" title="Instagram">
            Instagram
           </a>
           account reiterating Modi's claims and showing Rahul Gandhi holding a copy of the Congress Party's election manifesto that morphs into the symbol of the
           <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">
            All-India Muslim League
           </a>
           . After being flagged by multiple users, the video was taken down less than 24 hours after its publication.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-animation_169-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-animation-169">
             [165]
            </a>
           </sup>
           A similar video posted on X towards voters in
           <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">
            Karnataka
           </a>
           was also ordered taken down by the Electoral Commission and led to police opening cases against senior BJP leaders.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
            <a href="#cite_note-170">
             [166]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           A complaint letter by the
           <i>
            Samvidhan Bacchao Nagrik Abhiyan
           </i>
           (Save the Constitution Citizens' Campaign) organisation to the
           <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_India" title="Election Commission of India">
            Election Commission of India
           </a>
           , signed by over 17,400 people, alleged that Modi had violated the
           <a href="/wiki/Model_Code_of_Conduct" title="Model Code of Conduct">
            Model Code of Conduct
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Representation_of_the_People_Act,_1951" title="Representation of the People Act, 1951">
            Representation of the People Act, 1951
           </a>
           by making a speech "aiming at not only appealing to 'communal feelings' but also instigating and aggravating hatred in the Hindus against Muslims".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-india.com_143-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-india.com-143">
             [139]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scroll.in_144-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-scroll.in-144">
             [140]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           On 14 April 2024, the BJP invited
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_India" title="List of diplomatic missions in India">
            foreign diplomats
           </a>
           posted in the country as well as 25 overseas
           <a href="/wiki/Political_party" title="Political party">
            political parties
           </a>
           including the
           <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">
            Conservative
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">
            Labour
           </a>
           parties of the
           <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
            United Kingdom
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany" title="Christian Democratic Union of Germany">
            Christian Democratic Union of Germany
           </a>
           (CDU) and the
           <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" title="Social Democratic Party of Germany">
            Social Democratic Party of Germany
           </a>
           (SPD) of
           <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
            Germany
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">
            Awami League
           </a>
           of
           <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">
            Bangladesh
           </a>
           to observe the party's
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party_campaign_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="Bharatiya Janata Party campaign for the 2024 Indian general election">
            electoral campaign
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
            <a href="#cite_note-171">
             [167]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
            <a href="#cite_note-172">
             [168]
            </a>
           </sup>
           This initiative is part of the "Know BJP" campaign, aimed at external outreach and familiarisation with the
           <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_India" title="Elections in India">
            election process
           </a>
           . As part of this program, BJP president
           <a href="/wiki/J._P._Nadda" title="J. P. Nadda">
            J. P. Nadda
           </a>
           met with envoys from 13 countries.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
            <a href="#cite_note-173">
             [169]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
            <a href="#cite_note-174">
             [170]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance_2">
            Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           The bloc's first joint rally was held in
           <a href="/wiki/Patna" title="Patna">
            Patna
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">
            Bihar
           </a>
           on 3 March 2024. The rally saw, among others, Congress president
           <a href="/wiki/Mallikarjun_Kharge" title="Mallikarjun Kharge">
            Mallikarjun Kharge
           </a>
           , party leader
           <a href="/wiki/Rahul_Gandhi" title="Rahul Gandhi">
            Rahul Gandhi
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal" title="Rashtriya Janata Dal">
            Rashtriya Janata Dal
           </a>
           (RJD) chief
           <a href="/wiki/Lalu_Prasad_Yadav" title="Lalu Prasad Yadav">
            Lalu Prasad Yadav
           </a>
           , former Bihar deputy chief minister
           <a href="/wiki/Tejashwi_Yadav" title="Tejashwi Yadav">
            Tejashwi Yadav
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Samajwadi_Party" title="Samajwadi Party">
            Samajwadi Party
           </a>
           leader
           <a href="/wiki/Akhilesh_Yadav" title="Akhilesh Yadav">
            Akhilesh Yadav
           </a>
           , and senior
           <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)" title="Communist Party of India (Marxist)">
            Left
           </a>
           leaders
           <a href="/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury" title="Sitaram Yechury">
            Sitaram Yechury
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/D._Raja" title="D. Raja">
            D. Raja
           </a>
           . Kharge attacked Kumar for
           <a href="/wiki/Aaya_Ram_Gaya_Ram" title="Aaya Ram Gaya Ram">
            frequently changing alliances
           </a>
           and criticised the BJP for not fulfilling its promise of jobs and neglecting the country's poor and the majority.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
            <a href="#cite_note-175">
             [171]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           The alliance jointly held a rally at
           <a href="/wiki/Shivaji_Park" title="Shivaji Park">
            Shivaji Park
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">
            Mumbai
           </a>
           on 17 March, a day after the end of
           <a href="/wiki/Rahul_Gandhi" title="Rahul Gandhi">
            Rahul Gandhi
           </a>
           's
           <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra" title="Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra">
            Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra
           </a>
           . The rally was attended by Gandhi,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shiv_Sena_(Uddhav_Balasaheb_Thackeray)" title="Shiv Sena (Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray)">
            SS(UBT)
           </a>
           president
           <a href="/wiki/Uddhav_Thackeray" title="Uddhav Thackeray">
            Uddhav Thackeray
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nationalist_Congress_Party_(Sharadchandra_Pawar)" title="Nationalist Congress Party (Sharadchandra Pawar)">
            NCP(SP)
           </a>
           leader
           <a href="/wiki/Sharad_Pawar" title="Sharad Pawar">
            Sharad Pawar
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal" title="Rashtriya Janata Dal">
            RJD
           </a>
           leader
           <a href="/wiki/Tejashwi_Yadav" title="Tejashwi Yadav">
            Tejashwi Yadav
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="/wiki/Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam" title="Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam">
            DMK
           </a>
           leader and
           <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">
            Tamil Nadu
           </a>
           chief minister
           <a href="/wiki/M._K._Stalin" title="M. K. Stalin">
            M. K. Stalin
           </a>
           , among many others.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
            <a href="#cite_note-176">
             [172]
            </a>
           </sup>
           At the rally, Gandhi said that he was compelled to launch his yatra due to rising inflation and unemployment in the nation.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
            <a href="#cite_note-177">
             [173]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           A few days after arrest of Delhi chief minister
           <a href="/wiki/Arvind_Kejriwal" title="Arvind Kejriwal">
            Arvind Kejriwal
           </a>
           in connection with the alleged
           <a href="/wiki/Delhi_liquor_scam" title="Delhi liquor scam">
            Delhi liquor scam
           </a>
           on 22 March,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
            <a href="#cite_note-178">
             [174]
            </a>
           </sup>
           the opposition alliance held a protest rally against the same in
           <a href="/wiki/Ramlila_Maidan" title="Ramlila Maidan">
            Ramlila Maidan
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">
            Delhi
           </a>
           on 31 March, where opposition leaders alleged the corruption case on him and his subsequent arrest to be a "fabrication with political motives" and a "witch hunt".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
            <a href="#cite_note-179">
             [175]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
            <a href="#cite_note-180">
             [176]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
            <a href="#cite_note-181">
             [177]
            </a>
           </sup>
           At the rally, named "Loktantra Bachao" (Save Democracy), amid current events, the opposition tried to frame the election as being "democracy vs dictatorship".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
            <a href="#cite_note-182">
             [178]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_National_Congress_2">
            Indian National Congress
           </span>
          </h4>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress_campaign_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="Indian National Congress campaign for the 2024 Indian general election">
            Indian National Congress campaign for the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The Congress campaign was launched from
           <a href="/wiki/Nagpur" title="Nagpur">
            Nagpur
           </a>
           at a huge rally in which over 1 million people were expected to have attended on 28 December 2023.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
            <a href="#cite_note-183">
             [179]
            </a>
           </sup>
           This rally also marked the 138th Congress Foundation Day and was being held to energise party cadres for the 2024 general election.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Livemint_184-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Livemint-184">
             [180]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Party workers from all over the state were called to join the rally.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Livemint_184-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-Livemint-184">
             [180]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
            <a href="#cite_note-185">
             [181]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb">
           <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg">
            <img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg/220px-Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg/330px-Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg/440px-Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra_logo_%26_slogan.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
           </a>
           <figcaption>
            <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra" title="Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra">
             Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra
            </a>
            logo &amp; slogan
           </figcaption>
          </figure>
          <p>
           On 14 January, the party launched its
           <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra" title="Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra">
            Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra
           </a>
           ,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yatra_2.0_186-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Yatra_2.0-186">
             [182]
            </a>
           </sup>
           a sequel to the
           <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Jodo_Yatra" title="Bharat Jodo Yatra">
            Bharat Jodo Yatra
           </a>
           held the previous year.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
            <a href="#cite_note-187">
             [183]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Yatra" title="Yatra">
            yatra
           </a>
           started in
           <a href="/wiki/Thoubal" title="Thoubal">
            Thoubal
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Manipur" title="Manipur">
            Manipur
           </a>
           and ended in
           <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">
            Mumbai
           </a>
           on 16 March 2024.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yatra_2.0_186-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-Yatra_2.0-186">
             [182]
            </a>
           </sup>
           It covered 6,713 kilometres (4,171 miles) across 14 states.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
            <a href="#cite_note-188">
             [184]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb">
           <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg">
            <img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="2774" data-file-width="4160" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg/220px-%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg/330px-%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg/440px-%E0%A4%AD%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%A1%E0%A4%BC%E0%A5%8B_%E0%A4%A8%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AF_%E0%A4%AF%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
           </a>
           <figcaption>
            Attendees display banners at the gathering
           </figcaption>
          </figure>
          <p>
           Rahul Gandhi warned that the whole of India will be on fire if the BJP wins the 2024 parliamentary elections and changes the Constitution, during an address at Delhi's Ramlila Maidan.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hawk_2024_i967_189-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Hawk_2024_i967-189">
             [185]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khanduri_2024_d940_190-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Khanduri_2024_d940-190">
             [186]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bangalore_Mirror_2024_j240_191-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Bangalore_Mirror_2024_j240-191">
             [187]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Economic_Times_2024_n319_192-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-The_Economic_Times_2024_n319-192">
             [188]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h5>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Crowdfunding">
            Crowdfunding
           </span>
          </h5>
          <p>
           The Congress started a crowdfunding campaign known as
           <i>
            Donate for Desh
           </i>
           (Donate for the Country) ahead of the general elections. It formally launched the campaign's digital version on 18 December 2023 at a dedicated website. It claimed to be inspired from
           <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">
            Mahatma Gandhi
           </a>
           's Tilak Swaraj Fund (1920–21). The physical version of the campaign, which be done via door-to-door collection drives, was launched on 28 December.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
            <a href="#cite_note-193">
             [189]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
            <a href="#cite_note-194">
             [190]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           The campaign received
           <span class="nowrap">
            <span style="white-space: nowrap">
             ₹
            </span>
            1.45 crore
           </span>
           (US$170,000) on its first day, with the top five states in amount of donations being
           <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">
            Maharashtra
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Rajasthan" title="Rajasthan">
            Rajasthan
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">
            Uttar Pradesh
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">
            Delhi
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">
            Karnataka
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
            <a href="#cite_note-195">
             [191]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           By the end of 2023, the campaign received around
           <span class="nowrap">
            <span style="white-space: nowrap">
             ₹
            </span>
            9 crore
           </span>
           (US$1.1 million), with 30% of the funds being collected from
           <a href="/wiki/Telangana" title="Telangana">
            Telangana
           </a>
           and Maharashtra alone.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
            <a href="#cite_note-196">
             [192]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           The campaign had collected about
           <span class="nowrap">
            <span style="white-space: nowrap">
             ₹
            </span>
            20 crore
           </span>
           (US$2.4 million) according to the party when on 28 January, it rebranded its crowdfunding campaign to
           <i>
            Donate for Nyay
           </i>
           (Donate for Justice), in line with Rahul Gandhi's ongoing
           <a href="/wiki/Bharat_Jodo_Nyay_Yatra" title="Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra">
            Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
            <a href="#cite_note-197">
             [193]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The ensuing crowdfunding campaign collected four crores
           <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
            [
            <i>
             <a href="/wiki/Help:Convert_messages#needs_number" title="Help:Convert messages">
              <span title="Convert: Needs the number to be converted">
               convert: needs a number
              </span>
             </a>
            </i>
            ]
           </sup>
           <span class="error">
           </span>
           in 4 days.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
            <a href="#cite_note-198">
             [194]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h5>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Funding_issues">
            Funding issues
           </span>
          </h5>
          <p>
           On 16 February 2024, the Congress Party alleged that the
           <a href="/wiki/Income_Tax_Department" title="Income Tax Department">
            Income Tax Department
           </a>
           (IT) ordered the freezing of bank accounts by the Congress Party containing 2.1 billion rupees ($25.3 million) as part of an ongoing legal dispute.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frozen25m_199-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-frozen25m-199">
             [195]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The Congress Party's treasurer
           <a href="/wiki/Ajay_Maken" title="Ajay Maken">
            Ajay Maken
           </a>
           later added that tax authorities imposed a 2.1-billion rupee ($25 million)
           <a href="/wiki/Lien" title="Lien">
            lien
           </a>
           on 13 February, "virtually sealed" its bank accounts and confiscated 1.1 billion rupees ($14 million). The party's leader
           <a href="/wiki/Rahul_Gandhi" title="Rahul Gandhi">
            Rahul Gandhi
           </a>
           complained that the restrictions had rendered the party unable to campaign properly, adding that "Our entire financial identity has been erased." Gandhi also accused Modi and Home Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Amit_Shah" title="Amit Shah">
            Amit Shah
           </a>
           of conducting a "criminal action" against the party, which the BJP denied. His mother and former Congress leader
           <a href="/wiki/Sonia_Gandhi" title="Sonia Gandhi">
            Sonia Gandhi
           </a>
           also alleged that the tax issues are "part of the systemic efforts to cripple" the party. An appeal is currently pending in the Supreme Court.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
            <a href="#cite_note-200">
             [196]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           According to the IT Department's official sources, it has recovered
           <span style="white-space: nowrap">
            ₹
           </span>
           135 crore
           <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
            [
            <i>
             <a href="/wiki/Help:Convert_messages#needs_number" title="Help:Convert messages">
              <span title="Convert: Needs the number to be converted">
               convert: needs a number
              </span>
             </a>
            </i>
            ]
           </sup>
           <span class="error">
           </span>
           from the Congress for breaking the legislation exempting political parties from paying taxes, rather than freezing the party's bank accounts as the opposition party had claimed.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
            <a href="#cite_note-201">
             [197]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The party received notices from the IT department again on 29 March asking it to pay
           <span class="nowrap">
            <span style="white-space: nowrap">
             ₹
            </span>
            1,823.08 crore
           </span>
           (US$218 million). The Congress accused the BJP of engaging in "tax terrorism" and alleged that the BJP is in serious violation of
           <a href="/wiki/Income_tax_in_India" title="Income tax in India">
            income-tax laws
           </a>
           and that the IT department should raise a demand of
           <span class="nowrap">
            <span style="white-space: nowrap">
             ₹
            </span>
            4,617.58 crore
           </span>
           (US$553 million) crore
           <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
            [
            <i>
             <a href="/wiki/Help:Convert_messages#needs_number" title="Help:Convert messages">
              <span title="Convert: Needs the number to be converted">
               convert: needs a number
              </span>
             </a>
            </i>
            ]
           </sup>
           <span class="error">
           </span>
           from the BJP for such violations.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
            <a href="#cite_note-202">
             [198]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span id="Communist_Party_of_India_.28Marxist.29">
           </span>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)">
            Communist Party of India (Marxist)
           </span>
          </h4>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)_campaign_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election" title="Communist Party of India (Marxist) campaign for the 2024 Indian general election">
            Communist Party of India (Marxist) campaign for the 2024 Indian general election
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)" title="Communist Party of India (Marxist)">
            Communist Party of India (Marxist)
           </a>
           began their election campaign in Kerala after announcing 15 candidates in the state.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
            <a href="#cite_note-203">
             [199]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Rashtriya_Janata_Dal">
            Rashtriya Janata Dal
           </span>
          </h4>
          <p>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal" title="Rashtriya Janata Dal">
            Rashtriya Janata Dal
           </a>
           began its campaign with its
           <i>
            Jan Vishwas Yatra
           </i>
           ("People's Trust Yatra") on 20 February 2024. RJD leader
           <a href="/wiki/Tejashwi_Yadav" title="Tejashwi Yadav">
            Tejashwi Yadav
           </a>
           launched the yatra from
           <a href="/wiki/Muzaffarpur" title="Muzaffarpur">
            Muzaffarpur
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">
            Bihar
           </a>
           . The yatra lasted until 1 March 2024 and covered 33 districts.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
            <a href="#cite_note-204">
             [200]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
            <a href="#cite_note-205">
             [201]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In
           <a href="/wiki/Siwan,_Bihar" title="Siwan, Bihar">
            Siwan
           </a>
           on 23 February, Yadav termed the BJP "a dustbin" which takes in other parties that have become "garbage".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
            <a href="#cite_note-206">
             [202]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
            <a href="#cite_note-207">
             [203]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Aam_Aadmi_Party">
            Aam Aadmi Party
           </span>
          </h4>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Further information:
           <a href="/wiki/Arrest_of_Arvind_Kejriwal" title="Arrest of Arvind Kejriwal">
            Arrest of Arvind Kejriwal
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The election period also coincided with investigations by authorities into state officials belonging to opposition parties, such as
           <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">
            Delhi
           </a>
           Chief Minister and
           <a href="/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party" title="Aam Aadmi Party">
            Aam Aadmi Party
           </a>
           leader
           <a href="/wiki/Arvind_Kejriwal" title="Arvind Kejriwal">
            Arvind Kejriwal
           </a>
           , who is under investigation for alleged corruption in the
           <a href="/wiki/Delhi_liquor_scam" title="Delhi liquor scam">
            allocation of liquor licences
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="/wiki/Jharkhand" title="Jharkhand">
            Jharkhand
           </a>
           Chief Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Hemant_Soren" title="Hemant Soren">
            Hemant Soren
           </a>
           , who was arrested in February 2024 for allegedly facilitating an illegal land sale. The
           <a href="/wiki/Enforcement_Directorate" title="Enforcement Directorate">
            Enforcement Directorate
           </a>
           is also investigating four chief ministers not allied with the BJP on various charges, while investigations have been closed on former opposition politicians who have since joined the BJP.
           <a href="/wiki/Hartosh_Singh_Bal" title="Hartosh Singh Bal">
            Hartosh Singh Bal
           </a>
           , a journalist for the current affairs magazine
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/The_Caravan" title="The Caravan">
             The Caravan
            </a>
           </i>
           told
           <a href="/wiki/Agence_France-Presse" title="Agence France-Presse">
            Agence France-Presse
           </a>
           that the move by government agencies indicated their behavior as "handmaidens of the ruling party to cow down the political opposition".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frozen25m_199-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-frozen25m-199">
             [195]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           Following
           <a href="/wiki/Arrest_of_Arvind_Kejriwal" title="Arrest of Arvind Kejriwal">
            Kejriwal's arrest
           </a>
           on 21 March over the liquor license scam charges, Delhi's finance minister
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atishi_Singh" title="Atishi Singh">
            Atishi Marlena Singh
           </a>
           accused the BJP of orchestrating a "political conspiracy" against Kejriwal.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
            <a href="#cite_note-208">
             [204]
            </a>
           </sup>
           His arrest also led to clashes between party leaders, supporters and the police on 22 March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
            <a href="#cite_note-209">
             [205]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Rahul Gandhi, reacting to Kejriwal's arrest, said that a "scared dictator" wants to create a "dead democracy", without naming anyone.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
            <a href="#cite_note-210">
             [206]
            </a>
           </sup>
           After he was released on bail and allowed to vote, Kejriwal urged citizens to vote "vote against dictatorship".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
            <a href="#cite_note-211">
             [207]
            </a>
           </sup>
           He then returned to prison as part of his bail conditions.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
            <a href="#cite_note-212">
             [208]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           The BJP-led government has been known to use Enforcement Directorate raids to target opposition politicians critical of it, with 95% of cases registered being against opposition leaders.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
            <a href="#cite_note-213">
             [209]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
            <a href="#cite_note-214">
             [210]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
            <a href="#cite_note-215">
             [211]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Since 2014, 25 opposition leaders facing corruption charges have joined the BJP, with 23 of them having their inquiries closed or frozen after joining the ruling party.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
            <a href="#cite_note-216">
             [212]
            </a>
           </sup>
           This has led the Congress Party to compare the trend to a "washing machine" in one of its campaign videos.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-animation_169-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-animation-169">
             [165]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Shiv_Sena">
            Shiv Sena
           </span>
          </h4>
          <p>
           After an intraparty dispute that led to the splitting of the
           <a href="/wiki/Shiv_Sena" title="Shiv Sena">
            Shiv Sena
           </a>
           party based in
           <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">
            Maharashtra
           </a>
           , the Supreme Court of India barred the
           <a href="/wiki/Shiv_Sena_(UBT)" title="Shiv Sena (UBT)">
            Shiv Sena (UBT)
           </a>
           faction which joined the I.N.D.I.A. alliance from using the party's historic bow-and-arrow symbol as its electoral symbol in balloting and awarded it instead to the
           <a href="/wiki/Balasahebanchi_Shiv_Sena" title="Balasahebanchi Shiv Sena">
            Balasahebanchi Shiv Sena
           </a>
           wing which joined the NDA. This led the UBT faction to adopt a torch as its electoral symbol.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
            <a href="#cite_note-217">
             [213]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Party_manifestos">
            Party manifestos
           </span>
          </h3>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Bharatiya_Janata_Party_3">
            Bharatiya Janata Party
           </span>
          </h4>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party_campaign_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election#Manifesto" title="Bharatiya Janata Party campaign for the 2024 Indian general election">
            Bharatiya Janata Party campaign for the 2024 Indian general election § Manifesto
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The BJP proposed a 'GYAN' formula consisting of four segments – Garib (poor), Yuva (youth), Annadata (farmers) and Nari (women) in its manifesto.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
            <a href="#cite_note-218">
             [214]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The Bharatiya Janata Party started a campaign to gather public recommendations and suggestions for the advancement of the State and the country, which will be incorporated into the party's manifesto titled 'Modi ki guarantee' for the 2024 general elections.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
            <a href="#cite_note-219">
             [215]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
            <a href="#cite_note-220">
             [216]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
            <a href="#cite_note-221">
             [217]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
            <a href="#cite_note-222">
             [218]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
            <a href="#cite_note-223">
             [219]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
            <a href="#cite_note-224">
             [220]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
            <a href="#cite_note-225">
             [221]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <b>
             Nari Shakti Vandan Adhiniyam:
            </b>
            In order to assure women's representation in the legislatures of the states and the national leadership, the BJP pledged to systematically implement the Nari Shakti Vandan Adhiniyam.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Lakhpati Didi
            </b>
            : 30,000,000 rural women are being empowered to become "Lakhpati Didis".
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Free ration:
            </b>
            Under the PM Garib Kalyan Anna Yojana, the BJP announced that it would give 800,000,000 citizens free rations for the next five years.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Increasing MSP:
            </b>
            on crops on a periodic basis was pledged in the manifesto. 6,000 rupees in annual financial support under the PM Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Free electricity:
            </b>
            The PM Surya Ghar Muft Bijli Yojana's free power for low-income homes was another pledge in the manifesto.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             3 Crore house:
            </b>
            In the PM Housing Scheme, the BJP manifesto pledges to build 30,000,000 houses, people with disabilities will now be given priority, and care will be taken to make sure they are housed in accordance with their unique requirements.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             For youngsters:
            </b>
            BJP pledge to enact laws to stop the leak of competitive test question papers. Increase the startup ecosystem's reach to encourage youth entrepreneurship. Expanding job prospects in the manufacturing sector. Creating jobs through the development of infrastructure. Creating jobs through growing the tourism industry.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             For truck drivers:
            </b>
            Construction of modern buildings with facilities which allows truck drivers to rest, park, and have access to clean drinking water and food on all national highways.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             One Nation, One Election:
            </b>
            In its manifesto, or Sankalp Patra, the BJP includes "
            <a href="/wiki/One_Nation,_One_Election" title="One Nation, One Election">
             One Nation, One Election
            </a>
            ," for the general elections. This implies that simultaneous elections for the Lok Sabha and all the state assemblies may take place in 2029.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-onenation_226-0">
             <a href="#cite_note-onenation-226">
              [222]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Uniform Civil Code
            </b>
            : The manifesto includes the implementation of the
            <a href="/wiki/Uniform_Civil_Code" title="Uniform Civil Code">
             Uniform Civil Code
            </a>
            (UCC).
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
             <a href="#cite_note-227">
              [223]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Free Ayushman for all senior citizens:
            </b>
            Under the
            <a href="/wiki/Ayushman_Bharat_Yojana" title="Ayushman Bharat Yojana">
             Ayushman Bharat Yojana
            </a>
            , all senior citizens would be eligible for free, high-quality healthcare up to Rs 5 Lakhs.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             US$5 trillion economy
            </b>
            : The BJP pledges to increase India's GDP to
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">
             US$
            </a>
            5 trillion by 2025 and $10 trillion by 2032. The
            <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(India)" title="Ministry of Finance (India)">
             Ministry of Finance
            </a>
            has predicted that India's economy will rank third overall in the world.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
             <a href="#cite_note-228">
              [224]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
             <a href="#cite_note-229">
              [225]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Earlier in 2018 and then again in 2019, Modi had stated the goal of the country reaching a GDP of US$5 trillion by 2022 and 2024 respectively, which went unrealized.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
             <a href="#cite_note-230">
              [226]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
             <a href="#cite_note-231">
              [227]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             United Nations Security Council:
            </b>
            committed to securing India's
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" title="UN Security Council">
             UN Security Council
            </a>
            permanent membership.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Crack down on terrorism
            </b>
            :  Initiatives to create partnership to eliminate global terror and crack down on terror funding.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Left wing extremism
            </b>
            : Fighting Left-Wing Extremism by promoting growth and utilizing a variety of approaches.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Third-largest economic power
            </b>
            : India will rank as the country with the third-largest GDP. India's rank rose from the 11th to the 5th largest GDP in the last ten years.
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Man on Moon and Bharatiya Antariksha Station:
            </b>
            to establish a permanent
            <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Antariksha_Station" title="Bharatiya Antariksha Station">
             Bharatiya Antariksha Station
            </a>
            and send a man to the moon.
           </li>
          </ul>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_National_Congress_3">
            Indian National Congress
           </span>
          </h4>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
           Main article:
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress_campaign_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election#Manifesto" title="Indian National Congress campaign for the 2024 Indian general election">
            Indian National Congress campaign for the 2024 Indian general election § Manifesto
           </a>
          </div>
          <p>
           The Congress released their group-specific
           <a href="/wiki/Manifesto" title="Manifesto">
            manifesto
           </a>
           promises for the general election in the month of March.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
            <a href="#cite_note-232">
             [228]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The manifesto focuses on five major segments of the  population and promises them:
          </p>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <b>
             Youth Manifesto
            </b>
            : formal employment for a year to under 25 graduate students, filling of 3,000,000 government job vacancies, transparency in government job recruitment, ₹5,000 crore (US$605,000) fund for startups, standardisation of the government recruitment exam process, and social security for gig workers.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
             <a href="#cite_note-233">
              [229]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
             <a href="#cite_note-234">
              [230]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
             <a href="#cite_note-235">
              [231]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Women Manifesto
            </b>
            : ₹100,000 in financial assistance to women from poor families, 50% of new government job recruitments to women, double central government's contribution to the salary of
            <a href="/wiki/Anganwadi" title="Anganwadi">
             anganwadi
            </a>
            ,
            <a href="/wiki/Accredited_Social_Health_Activist" title="Accredited Social Health Activist">
             ASHA
            </a>
            , and
            <a href="/wiki/Midday_Meal_Scheme" title="Midday Meal Scheme">
             midday meal workers
            </a>
            , legal assistance in every
            <a href="/wiki/Panchayati_raj" title="Panchayati raj">
             panchayat
            </a>
            , and at least one hostel for working women in district headquarters.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
             <a href="#cite_note-236">
              [232]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
             <a href="#cite_note-237">
              [233]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Farmers Manifesto
            </b>
            : legal guarantee on
            <a href="/wiki/Minimum_support_price_(India)" title="Minimum support price (India)">
             MSP
            </a>
            for farmers, waiving off of farmers' loans, an import-export policy favourable to them, removal of
            <a href="/wiki/Goods_and_Services_Tax_(India)" title="Goods and Services Tax (India)">
             GST
            </a>
            from agricultural commodities, and payments directly into farmers' bank accounts within 30 days in case of crop loss.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
             <a href="#cite_note-238">
              [234]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Labourers Manifesto
            </b>
            : Universal healthcare coverage for workers, increasing national minimum wage to ₹400 (
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">
             US$
            </a>
            4.8) per day from the current ₹172 (
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">
             US$
            </a>
            2.1) per day, an urban employment guarantee law similar to
            <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi_National_Rural_Employment_Guarantee_Act,_2005" title="Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005">
             MGNREGA
            </a>
            in the rural areas, life and accident insurance for informal sector workers.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
             <a href="#cite_note-239">
              [235]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
             <a href="#cite_note-240">
              [236]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Caste census
            </b>
            : The Congress party declared that, if it wins the election, it will conduct a comprehensive census called to survey the population, socio-economic conditions, and representation in governance institutions. It also promised to bring in legislation to eliminate the 50% cap on reservations for SC, ST, and backward classes and to protect tribal forest rights.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
             <a href="#cite_note-241">
              [237]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Rahul Gandhi's call for "jitni abadi, utna haq" (distribution of public resources proportionate to the population) and the combined demands of the opposition parties (SP, RJD, and Congress) for a caste census.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
             <a href="#cite_note-242">
              [238]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
          </ul>
          <p>
           The complete manifesto titled
           <i>
            Nyay Patra
           </i>
           (
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindi_language" title="Hindi language">
            Hindi
           </a>
           :
           <span lang="hi">
            न्याय पत्र
           </span>
           ,
           <small>
            <a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">
             lit.
            </a>
           </small>
           'Justice Paper') was released on 5 April 2024.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
            <a href="#cite_note-243">
             [239]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
            <a href="#cite_note-244">
             [240]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Some noticeable points in the manifesto include (apart from above promises released earlier) the:
          </p>
          <ul>
           <li>
            Introduction of a law to recognize civil unions between couples belonging to the
            <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">
             LGBTQIA+ community
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            Implementation of the
            <a href="/wiki/Third_Gehlot_ministry" title="Third Gehlot ministry">
             Rajasthan Model
            </a>
            of cashless insurance up to 2,500,000 for
            <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">
             universal healthcare
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            Prohibitions on dumping of effluents into water bodies across India.
           </li>
           <li>
            Increasing of forest cover as India has lost the second – highest forest cover after Brazil between 2015 and 2020.
           </li>
           <li>
            Establishment of community sports centers at every block and municipality level as well as multi – sport center at every district level.
           </li>
           <li>
            Establishment of government medical colleges – cum – hospitals in all districts of India.
           </li>
           <li>
            Abolition of the
            <a href="/wiki/Agnipath_Scheme" title="Agnipath Scheme">
             Agnipath Scheme
            </a>
            and a return to the normal recruitment processes followed by the Army, Navy and Air Force.
           </li>
           <li>
            Waiving of student education loans as a one – time measure outstanding as of 15 March 2024.
           </li>
           <li>
            Provision of one day in a week to discuss the agenda suggested by the opposition benches in each
            <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">
             House of Parliament
            </a>
            .
           </li>
           <li>
            Non – intervention with personal choices of food and dress, to love and marry, and to travel and reside in any part of India. All laws and rules that interfere unreasonably with personal freedoms will be repealed.
           </li>
           <li>
            Decriminalisation of the offence of defamation and provide, by law, a speedy remedy by way of civil damages.
           </li>
           <li>
            Rejection of the 'One Nation One Election' idea.
           </li>
           <li>
            Establishment of a National Judicial Commission (NJC) responsible for the selection and appointment of judges of the High Courts and the Supreme Court.
           </li>
           <li>
            Amending of the Constitution to create two divisions in the Supreme Court: a Constitutional Court and a Court of Appeal. The Constitutional Court consisting of the seven most senior judges will hear and decide cases involving the interpretation of the Constitution and other cases of legal significance or national importance. The Court of Appeal will be the final court of appeal that will, sitting in Benches of three judges each, hear appeals from the High Court and National Tribunals.
           </li>
           <li>
            Elimination of the "Angel tax" and all other exploitative tax schemes that inhibit investment in new micro, small companies and innovative start-ups.
           </li>
          </ul>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Surveys_and_polls">
            Surveys and polls
           </span>
          </h2>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Opinion_polls">
            Opinion polls
           </span>
          </h3>
          <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
          <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable relarticle mainarticle selfreference noprint" role="note">
           This section is
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Transclusion" title="Help:Transclusion">
            transcluded
           </a>
           from
           <a href="/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election#Seats_and_vote_share_projections" title="Opinion polling for the 2024 Indian general election">
            Opinion polling for the 2024 Indian general election#Seats and vote share projections
           </a>
           .
           <span class="plainlinks" style="font-style: normal; font-size:85%;">
            (
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=edit#Seats_and_vote_share_projections">
             edit
            </a>
            |
            <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election&amp;action=history#Seats_and_vote_share_projections">
             history
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </div>
          <figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File/Thumb">
           <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg">
            <img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1620" decoding="async" height="389" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg/700px-Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg/1050px-Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg/1400px-Opinion_polling_for_the_2024_Indian_general_election.svg.png 2x" width="700"/>
           </a>
           <figcaption>
            Vote share projections
           </figcaption>
          </figure>

            Vote share projections
           </caption>

             </th>

              Date published
             </th>

             </th>

              Margin of error
             </th>
             <td bgcolor="#F98C1F">
             </td>
             <td bgcolor="#00B7EB">
             </td>

             </td>
             <th rowspan="2">
              Lead
             </th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
             <th>
              <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">
               NDA
              </a>
             </th>
             <th>
              <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Developmental_Inclusive_Alliance" title="Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance">
               INDIA
              </a>
             </th>
             <th>
              Others
             </th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
             <td>
              <a href="/wiki/ABP_News" title="ABP News">
               ABP News
              </a>
              -
              <a href="/wiki/CVoter" title="CVoter">
               CVoter
              </a>
             </td>
             <td>
              <i>
               April 2024
              </i>

          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Exit_polls">
            Exit polls
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           The Election Commission of India banned the publication of all
           <a href="/wiki/Exit_poll" title="Exit poll">
            exit polls
           </a>
           starting 48 hours before Phase 1 of the election until the end of Phase 7. This was intended to prevent exit polls from earlier phases affecting voter decisions in later phases. The ban ended after the close of Phase 7 voting at 18:30 IST on 1 June 2024.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
            <a href="#cite_note-283">
             [279]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;font-size:95%;line-height:30px;">
           <tbody>
            <tr>
