          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Voting">
            Voting
           </span>
          </h2>
          <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb">
           <a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Polling_officials_are_carrying_Electronic_Voting_Machine_(EVMs)_and_other_election_related_materials_required_for_the_5th_Phase_of_General_Elections-2024_at_Serampore,_in_West_Bengal_on_May_19,_2024.jpg">
            <img class="mw-file-element" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Polling_officials_are_carrying_Electronic_Voting_Machine_%28EVMs%29_and_other_election_related_materials_required_for_the_5th_Phase_of_General_Elections-2024_at_Serampore%2C_in_West_Bengal_on_May_19%2C_2024.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Polling_officials_are_carrying_Electronic_Voting_Machine_%28EVMs%29_and_other_election_related_materials_required_for_the_5th_Phase_of_General_Elections-2024_at_Serampore%2C_in_West_Bengal_on_May_19%2C_2024.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Polling_officials_are_carrying_Electronic_Voting_Machine_%28EVMs%29_and_other_election_related_materials_required_for_the_5th_Phase_of_General_Elections-2024_at_Serampore%2C_in_West_Bengal_on_May_19%2C_2024.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
           </a>
           <figcaption>
            Polling officials carrying Electronic Voting Machine (EVMs) and other election related materials for the 5th Phase of the General Elections at
            <a href="/wiki/Serampore" title="Serampore">
             Serampore
            </a>
            ,
            <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">
             West Bengal
            </a>
            on 19 May 2024.
           </figcaption>
          </figure>
          <ul>
           <li>
            The Phase 1 voting was conducted on 19 April 2024.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
             <a href="#cite_note-292">
              [288]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
             <a href="#cite_note-293">
              [289]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Re-polling in 11 polling stations of
            <a href="/wiki/Inner_Manipur_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Inner Manipur Lok Sabha constituency">
             Inner Manipur
            </a>
            was held on 22 April due to violence.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
             <a href="#cite_note-294">
              [290]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
             <a href="#cite_note-295">
              [291]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Re-polling was conducted for eight polling stations in
            <a href="/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh" title="Arunachal Pradesh">
             Arunachal Pradesh
            </a>
            on 24 April due to reports of violence and EVM damage.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
             <a href="#cite_note-296">
              [292]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
             <a href="#cite_note-297">
              [293]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            The Phase 2 voting was conducted on 26 April 2024.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
             <a href="#cite_note-298">
              [294]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
             <a href="#cite_note-299">
              [295]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Re-polling was conducted on 29 April for a polling station in
            <a href="/wiki/Chamarajanagar_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Chamarajanagar Lok Sabha constituency">
             Chamarajanagar
            </a>
            due to violence and EVM damage
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
             <a href="#cite_note-300">
              [296]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
             <a href="#cite_note-301">
              [297]
             </a>
            </sup>
            and for six polling stations in
            <a href="/wiki/Outer_Manipur_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Outer Manipur Lok Sabha constituency">
             Outer Manipur
            </a>
            on 30 April due to violence, EVM damage and forced voting allegedly carried out by unidentified armed individuals.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
             <a href="#cite_note-302">
              [298]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
             <a href="#cite_note-303">
              [299]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Re-polling was also conducted for a polling station in
            <a href="/wiki/Ajmer_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Ajmer Lok Sabha constituency">
             Ajmer
            </a>
            on 2 May 2024 due to misplaced voters' register.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
             <a href="#cite_note-304">
              [300]
             </a>
            </sup>
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
             <a href="#cite_note-305">
              [301]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            The Phase 3 voting was conducted on 7 May 2024. The voter turnout for the third phase of Lok Sabha elections reached 65.68%. In this phase, 17.24 crore (172,400,000) citizens, comprising 8.85 crore (88,500,000) men and 8.39 crore (83,900,000) women, were eligible to cast their votes.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
             <a href="#cite_note-306">
              [302]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            The Phase 4 voting was conducted on 13 May 2024, where 96 constituencies voted.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
             <a href="#cite_note-307">
              [303]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            The Phase 5 voting was conducted on 20 May 2024, where 49 constituencies voted.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-apphase5_168-1">
             <a href="#cite_note-apphase5-168">
              [164]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            The Phase 6 voting was conducted on 25 May 2024, where 58 constituencies voted.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
             <a href="#cite_note-308">
              [304]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li>
            The Phase 7 voting was conducted on 1 June 2024, where 57 constituencies voted.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_309-0">
             <a href="#cite_note-:3-309">
              [305]
             </a>
            </sup>
            Repolling at one booth each in the
            <a href="/wiki/Barasat_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Barasat Lok Sabha constituency">
             Barasat
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Mathurapur_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Mathurapur Lok Sabha constituency">
             Mathurapur
            </a>
            constituencies of West Bengal were held on 3 June due to violence.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
             <a href="#cite_note-310">
              [306]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
          </ul>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Incidents">
            Incidents
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           During Phase 1 of the election, violence broke out outside a polling station in Thamanpokpi in
           <a href="/wiki/Manipur" title="Manipur">
            Manipur
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
            <a href="#cite_note-311">
             [307]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
            <a href="#cite_note-312">
             [308]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Clashes between
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
            BJP
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Trinamool_Congress" title="Trinamool Congress">
            TMC
           </a>
           party workers were reported in the
           <a href="/wiki/Cooch_Behar_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Cooch Behar Lok Sabha constituency">
            Cooch Behar
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Alipurduars_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Alipurduars Lok Sabha constituency">
            Alipurduar
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Jalpaiguri_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Jalpaiguri Lok Sabha constituency">
            Jalpaiguri
           </a>
           constituencies of
           <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">
            West Bengal
           </a>
           ,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
            <a href="#cite_note-313">
             [309]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
            <a href="#cite_note-314">
             [310]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and one
           <a href="/wiki/Central_Reserve_Police_Force" title="Central Reserve Police Force">
            Central Reserve Police Force
           </a>
           (CPRF) personnel was found dead in a polling booth in
           <a href="/wiki/Cooch_Behar" title="Cooch Behar">
            Cooch Behar
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
            <a href="#cite_note-315">
             [311]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
            <a href="#cite_note-316">
             [312]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In
           <a href="/wiki/Chhattisgarh" title="Chhattisgarh">
            Chhattisgarh
           </a>
           , one
           <a href="/wiki/Central_Reserve_Police_Force" title="Central Reserve Police Force">
            CRPF
           </a>
           personnel was killed during polling.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
            <a href="#cite_note-317">
             [313]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
            <a href="#cite_note-318">
             [314]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Clashes between
           <a href="/wiki/Viduthalai_Chiruthaigal_Katchi" title="Viduthalai Chiruthaigal Katchi">
            VCK
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">
            BJP
           </a>
           cadres were reported in
           <a href="/wiki/Chidambaram_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Chidambaram Lok Sabha constituency">
            Chidambaram constituency
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">
            Tamil Nadu
           </a>
           , where two VCK cadres and one BJP cadre were injured.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
            <a href="#cite_note-319">
             [315]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
            <a href="#cite_note-320">
             [316]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           During Phase 2 of voting, eight voters in
           <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">
            Kerala
           </a>
           died of
           <a href="/wiki/Heat_stroke" title="Heat stroke">
            heat stroke
           </a>
           while voting.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
            <a href="#cite_note-321">
             [317]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
            <a href="#cite_note-322">
             [318]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In Manipur, two CPRF personnel were killed and two more were seriously injured in a militant attack in
           <a href="/wiki/Bishnupur_district" title="Bishnupur district">
            Bishnupur district
           </a>
           ,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
            <a href="#cite_note-323">
             [319]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
            <a href="#cite_note-324">
             [320]
            </a>
           </sup>
           a man was killed in a gunfight between two unidentified groups in the
           <a href="/wiki/Kangpokpi_district" title="Kangpokpi district">
            Kangpokpi
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Imphal_East_district" title="Imphal East district">
            Imphal East
           </a>
           districts,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
            <a href="#cite_note-325">
             [321]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
            <a href="#cite_note-326">
             [322]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and incidents of EVM vandalism, voter intimidation and coercion were reported in two polling stations in
           <a href="/wiki/Ukhrul" title="Ukhrul">
            Ukhrul
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
            <a href="#cite_note-327">
             [323]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
            <a href="#cite_note-328">
             [324]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           A complaint letter by the
           <i>
            Samvidhan Bacchao Nagrik Abhiyan
           </i>
           (Save the Constitution Citizens' Campaign) organisation to the
           <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_India" title="Election Commission of India">
            Election Commission of India
           </a>
           , signed by over 17,400 people, alleged that Modi had violated the
           <a href="/wiki/Model_Code_of_Conduct" title="Model Code of Conduct">
            Model Code of Conduct
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Representation_of_the_People_Act,_1951" title="Representation of the People Act, 1951">
            Representation of the People Act, 1951
           </a>
           by making a speech "aiming at not only appealing to 'communal feelings' but also instigating and aggravating hatred in the Hindus against Muslims".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
            <a href="#cite_note-329">
             [325]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
            <a href="#cite_note-330">
             [326]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           During Phase 6 of voting,
           <a href="/wiki/Mehbooba_Mufti" title="Mehbooba Mufti">
            Mehbooba Mufti
           </a>
           , who is contesting the
           <a href="/wiki/Anantnag%E2%80%93Rajouri_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Anantnag–Rajouri Lok Sabha constituency">
            Anantnag–Rajouri constituency
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">
            Jammu and Kashmir
           </a>
           for the
           <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_People%27s_Democratic_Party" title="Jammu and Kashmir People's Democratic Party">
            Jammu and Kashmir People's Democratic Party
           </a>
           , said several of her party workers were detained by police to prevent them from voting. In West Bengal, TMC workers blocked the car of BJP candidate
           <a href="/wiki/Agnimitra_Paul" title="Agnimitra Paul">
            Agnimitra Paul
           </a>
           while she was on her way to vote in the
           <a href="/wiki/Medinipur_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Medinipur Lok Sabha constituency">
            Medinipur constituency
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
            <a href="#cite_note-331">
             [327]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Prashant Jagdev, the BJP candidate for the
           <a href="/wiki/2024_Odisha_Legislative_Assembly_election" title="2024 Odisha Legislative Assembly election">
            2024 Odisha Legislative Assembly election
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Begunia_Assembly_constituency" title="Begunia Assembly constituency">
            Begunia
           </a>
           , was arrested on suspicion of vandalising an EVM.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-v674_332-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-v674-332">
             [328]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           During Phase 7 of voting, a mob looted election material from a polling booth and dumped it into a pond in
           <a href="/wiki/Kultali" title="Kultali">
            Kultali
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Jaynagar_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Jaynagar Lok Sabha constituency">
            Jaynagar
           </a>
           in West Bengal. Clashes erupted between BJP and TMC supporters in
           <a href="/wiki/Sandeshkhali" title="Sandeshkhali">
            Sandeshkhali
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
            <a href="#cite_note-333">
             [329]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In
           <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">
            Uttar Pradesh
           </a>
           , at least 33 election workers, including security and sanitation staff, died of heat stroke, along with a voter waiting in line in
           <a href="/wiki/Ballia" title="Ballia">
            Ballia
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
            <a href="#cite_note-334">
             [330]
            </a>
           </sup>
           State election officials subsequently stated that compensation of 1.5 million rupees ($18,000) would be given to the families of the deceased workers.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
            <a href="#cite_note-335">
             [331]
            </a>
           </sup>
           At least ten election related deaths were also reported in
           <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">
            Bihar
           </a>
           that day.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
            <a href="#cite_note-336">
             [332]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In response to the ongoing heatwave, ECI chief
           <a href="/wiki/Rajiv_Kumar_(civil_servant)" title="Rajiv Kumar (civil servant)">
            Rajiv Kumar
           </a>
           said they had learned a lesson and "should have completed the election at least one month before".
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337">
            <a href="#cite_note-337">
             [333]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           Instances of EVM malfunctioning and removal of candidates belonging to the opposition were reported throughout the elections.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-o430_338-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-o430-338">
             [334]
            </a>
           </sup>
           On 18 April, the Supreme Court asked the ECI to look into reported EVM malfunctioning in Kerala.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-e533_13-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-e533-13">
             [12]
            </a>
           </sup>
           150 EVMs were replaced in
           <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">
            Assam
           </a>
           after reported malfunctioning.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-m927_339-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-m927-339">
             [335]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In
           <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">
            Varanasi
           </a>
           , about 33 nominations challenging Narendra Modi were rejected, of which 8 applicants claimed that the process was rigged in favour of the BJP.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-e827_14-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-e827-14">
             [13]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           On 4 June, former
           <a href="/wiki/Chhattisgarh" title="Chhattisgarh">
            Chhattisgarh
           </a>
           Chief Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Bhupesh_Baghel" title="Bhupesh Baghel">
            Bhupesh Baghel
           </a>
           said there was a discrepancy in EVM numbers while former
           <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">
            Uttar Pradesh
           </a>
           Chief Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Akhilesh_Yadav" title="Akhilesh Yadav">
            Akhilesh Yadav
           </a>
           accused the administration of carrying out arrests of his party workers in order to stop them from counting votes.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49464H_340-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-49464H-340">
             [336]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Misinformation">
            Misinformation
           </span>
          </h2>
          <p>
           Narendra Modi, on 21 April during an election campaign rally in Rajasthan, falsely claimed that former Prime Minister
           <a href="/wiki/Manmohan_Singh" title="Manmohan Singh">
            Manmohan Singh
           </a>
           once said "Muslims have the first right on the country's resources". However, Singh's speech also mentioned backward communities, including
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scheduled_caste" title="Scheduled caste">
            scheduled castes
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scheduled_tribe" title="Scheduled tribe">
            scheduled tribes
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Other_Backward_Class" title="Other Backward Class">
            Other Backward Classes
           </a>
           , women, children, and minorities.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-g511_341-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-g511-341">
             [337]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Modi falsely claimed that Rahul Gandhi had not named
           <a href="/wiki/Gautam_Adani" title="Gautam Adani">
            Gautam Adani
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Mukesh_Ambani" title="Mukesh Ambani">
            Mukesh Ambani
           </a>
           throughout the elections. Gandhi had mentioned Adani and Ambani about 25 times.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-w198_342-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-w198-342">
             [338]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           The BJP was accused by the opposition of doctoring videos.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
            <a href="#cite_note-343">
             [339]
            </a>
           </sup>
           On 3 June,
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">
             Time
            </a>
           </i>
           noted throughout the elections, associates and supporters of the BJP circulated fake news in order to discredit its opponents and spread hatred against religious minorities.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-g369_344-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-g369-344">
             [340]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Voter_turnout">

          </div>
          <p>
           Following the first round, the BJP won its first seat after
           <a href="/wiki/Mukesh_Dalal" title="Mukesh Dalal">
            Mukesh Dalal
           </a>
           , its candidate for
           <a href="/wiki/Surat_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Surat Lok Sabha constituency">
            Surat constituency
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">
            Gujarat
           </a>
           , was elected unopposed following rejection and withdrawal of other candidates.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
            <a href="#cite_note-349">
             [345]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350">
            <a href="#cite_note-350">
             [346]
            </a>
           </sup>
           No voting was held in the constituency, as the ECI had certified the results two weeks prior due to the absence of rival candidates.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
            <a href="#cite_note-351">
             [347]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           The overall election result was described in several media sources as a "shock" to Narendra Modi,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
            <a href="#cite_note-352">
             [348]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353">
            <a href="#cite_note-353">
             [349]
            </a>
           </sup>
           with the BJP falling short of its
           <a href="/wiki/Abki_Baar_400_Paar" title="Abki Baar 400 Paar">
            expectations of winning 400 seats
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
            <a href="#cite_note-354">
             [350]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Though pre-poll predictions were for an overwhelming majority for the BJP, the INDIA bloc performed much better than exit polls had predicted it to,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355">
            <a href="#cite_note-355">
             [351]
            </a>
           </sup>
           with upset victories in major states such as
           <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">
            Uttar Pradesh
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">
            Maharashtra
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">
            West Bengal
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356">
            <a href="#cite_note-356">
             [352]
            </a>
           </sup>
           The BJP had to rely on the 28 cumulative seats won by the
           <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">
            Andhra Pradesh
           </a>
           -based
           <a href="/wiki/Telugu_Desam_Party" title="Telugu Desam Party">
            Telugu Desam Party
           </a>
           led by
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chandrababu_Naidu" title="Chandrababu Naidu">
            Chandrababu Naidu
           </a>
           and the
           <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">
            Bihar
           </a>
           -based
           <a href="/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)" title="Janata Dal (United)">
            Janata Dal (United)
           </a>
           led by
           <a href="/wiki/Nitish_Kumar" title="Nitish Kumar">
            Nitish Kumar
           </a>
           in order for the NDA to retain its majority in the Lok Sabha.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357">
            <a href="#cite_note-357">
             [353]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358">
            <a href="#cite_note-358">
             [354]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359">
            <a href="#cite_note-359">
             [355]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="By_alliance_and_party">

          <h2>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Aftermath">
            Aftermath
           </span>
          </h2>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Reactions">
            Reactions
           </span>
          </h3>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="National">
            National
           </span>
          </h4>
          <p>
           Narendra Modi called the NDA's lead "a historical feat in India's history", while Congress party president Mallikarjun Kharge said the election was a "moral and political loss" for Modi and a "win for democracy" and the public.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361">
            <a href="#cite_note-361">
             [357]
            </a>
           </sup>
           In a speech to his supporters on 4 June, Modi said that the NDA would form a third consecutive government.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
            <a href="#cite_note-362">
             [358]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Following a meeting with other members of the NDA on 5 June, Modi was formally endorsed to become prime minister again.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363">
            <a href="#cite_note-363">
             [359]
            </a>
           </sup>
           On 7 June, he was selected as leader of the NDA
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364">
            <a href="#cite_note-364">
             [360]
            </a>
           </sup>
           and was inaugurated as prime minister on 9 June.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365">
            <a href="#cite_note-365">
             [361]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <p>
           <a href="/wiki/Sangli_Lok_Sabha_constituency" title="Sangli Lok Sabha constituency">
            Sangli
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Independent_politician" title="Independent politician">
            independent
           </a>
           MP
           <a href="/wiki/Vishal_Patil" title="Vishal Patil">
            Vishal Patil
           </a>
           , who is a primary member of the Congress party, extended support to it after the election, in effect increasing the opposition alliance tally to 235.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366">
            <a href="#cite_note-366">
             [362]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367">
            <a href="#cite_note-367">
             [363]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368">
            <a href="#cite_note-368">
             [364]
            </a>
           </sup>
           On 8 June, the leadership of the Congress Party unanimously nominated Rahul Gandhi to become
           <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_(India)" title="Leader of the Opposition (India)">
            Leader of the Opposition
           </a>
           , a position which had been vacant since 2014.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369">
            <a href="#cite_note-369">
             [365]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h4>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="International">
            International
           </span>
          </h4>
          <p>
           Leaders and officials of
           <a href="/wiki/Antigua_and_Barbuda" title="Antigua and Barbuda">
            Antigua and Barbuda
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">
            Argentina
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">
            Armenia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">
            Australia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
            Austria
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">
            Bahrain
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">
            Bangladesh
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Barbados" title="Barbados">
            Barbados
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">
            Belgium
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">
            Belize
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Benin" title="Benin">
            Benin
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">
            Bhutan
           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">
            Bolivia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
            Brazil
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">
            Cambodia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">
            Canada
           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
            China
           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/Comoros" title="Comoros">
            Comoros
           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">
            Croatia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">
            Cyprus
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">
            Czech Republic
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
            Denmark
           </a>

           </a>

            Greece

           <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">
            Guyana
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">
            Honduras
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
            Iceland
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">
            Indonesia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
            Iran
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">
            Iraq
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">
            Israel
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
            Italy
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">
            Jamaica
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">
            Japan
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">
            Kenya
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
            Latvia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">
            Lithuania
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">
            Maldives
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">
            Madagascar
           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">
            Malaysia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">
            Mauritius
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">
            Moldova
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">
            Nepal
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
            Netherlands
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">
            New Zealand
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">
            Nigeria
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">
            Norway
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">
            Pakistan
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">
            Philippines
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
            Russia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Saint_Kitts_and_Nevis" title="Saint Kitts and Nevis">
            Saint Kitts and Nevis
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
            Serbia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">
            Singapore
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">
            Slovenia
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">
            South Korea
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
            Spain
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">
            Sri Lanka
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
            Sweden
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">
            Taiwan
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">
            Tanzania
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">
            Thailand
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timor_Leste" title="Timor Leste">
            Timor Leste
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Uganda" title="Uganda">
            Uganda
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
            Ukraine
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">
            United Arab Emirates
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
            United Kingdom
           </a>
           , the
           <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
            United States
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">
            Vietnam
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">
            Yemen
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">
            Zambia
           </a>
           congratulated Modi on the victory.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370">
            <a href="#cite_note-370">
             [366]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371">
            <a href="#cite_note-371">
             [367]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372">
            <a href="#cite_note-372">
             [368]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373">
            <a href="#cite_note-373">
             [369]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374">
            <a href="#cite_note-374">
             [370]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375">
            <a href="#cite_note-375">
             [371]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376">
            <a href="#cite_note-376">
             [372]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377">
            <a href="#cite_note-377">
             [373]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Stock_markets">
            Stock markets
           </span>
          </h3>
          <p>
           The benchmark
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BSE_Sensex" title="BSE Sensex">
            BSE Sensex
           </a>
           and
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nifty50" title="Nifty50">
            Nifty50
           </a>
           indices hit intraday record highs and the
           <a href="/wiki/Indian_rupee" title="Indian rupee">
            Indian rupee
           </a>
           strengthened after the exit polls were released. However, on the day results were announced, Indian stock markets crashed.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378">
            <a href="#cite_note-378">
             [374]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Rahul Gandhi subsequently called for an investigation, saying that Modi, Amit Shah and finance minister
           <a href="/wiki/Nirmala_Sitharaman" title="Nirmala Sitharaman">
            Nirmala Sitharaman
           </a>
           had misled investors into buying stocks before the release of the election results on 4 June in anticipation of a landslide victory by the BJP.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379">
            <a href="#cite_note-379">
             [375]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </p>
          <h3>
           <span class="mw-headline" id="Oath_taking_and_government_formation">

           </span>
          </h3>

           </a>
          </div>

                </a>
                on 20 April 2024

                 </span>

                </span>

                Walia, Aggam (21 September 2023).
                <span class="id-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required">
                 <a class="external text" href="https://indianexpress.com/article/business/42-3-of-graduates-under-25-unemployed-finds-latest-state-of-working-india-report-8949124/" rel="nofollow">

                 </a>
                </span>

                </i>

               <cite class="citation news cs1">

                 </i>
                </sup>
               </a>
               <a href="#cite_ref-:20_285-7">

                 <i>
                  <b>

               </a>

               <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Wire&amp;rft.atitle=Fact-Check%3A+Did+PM+Modi+Lie+About+Manmohan+Singh+s+First+Claim+Statement%3F&amp;rft.date=2024-04-23&amp;rft.aulast=Kaskar&amp;rft.aufirst=Zeeshan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fm.thewire.in%2Farticle%2Fcommunalism%2Fmodi-muslims-manmohan-sigh-first-claim%2Famp&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A2024+Indian+general+election">
               </span>
              </span>

                  <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=X+%28formerly+Twitter%29&amp;rft.atitle=x.com&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fx.com%2FLawrenceWongST%2Fstatus%2F1798204297802608655&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A2024+Indian+general+election">
                  </span>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Sri Lanka:
                  <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
                  <cite class="citation web cs1">
                   <a class="external text" href="https://x.com/RW_UNP/status/1798019368674275413" rel="nofollow">
                    "x.com"
                   </a>
                   .
                   <i>
                    X (formerly Twitter)
                   </i>
                   .
                  </cite>
                  <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=X+%28formerly+Twitter%29&amp;rft.atitle=x.com&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fx.com%2FRW_UNP%2Fstatus%2F1798019368674275413&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A2024+Indian+general+election">
                  </span>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  PM Modi:
                  <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1215172403" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>

                   </i>
